& =\int_{E}\left(\int_{E} P_{\text {sy }}(\bar{x}-\bar{y}) \psi_{\tau_{0}}(\bar{x}-\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y})\right)\left(\int_{E} P_{\text {sy }}(\bar{x}-\bar{z}) \psi_{\tau_{0}}(\bar{x}-\bar{z}) \mathrm{d} H(\bar{z})\right) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{x}) \\
& =\int_{E}\left(\int_{E}\left(\int_{E} P_{\text {sy }}(\bar{x}-\bar{y}) \psi_{\tau_{0}}(\bar{x}-\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y})\right) P_{\text {sy }}(\bar{z}-\bar{x}) \psi_{\tau_{0}}(\bar{z}-\bar{x}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{x})\right) \mathrm{d} H(\bar{z}) \\
& =\int_{E} \mathcal{S}_{\nu}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{z}) \mathrm{d} H(\bar{z})
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, we may rewrite $\int_{E}\left|\mathcal{S} \mu_{\lambda}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{\lambda}$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{E}\left|\mathcal{S} \mu_{\lambda}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{\lambda}=\int_{E}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}+\lambda\left[\int_{E}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} H+2 \int_{E} \mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right) \mathrm{d} H\right] \\
& +\lambda^{2}\left[\int_{E}(\mathcal{S} H)^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}+2 \int_{E} \mathcal{S}_{H}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right) \mathrm{d} H\right]+\lambda^{3} \int_{E}(\mathcal{S} H)^{2} \mathrm{~d} H
\end{aligned}
$$

So condition $F\left(\mu_{0}\right) \geq F\left(\mu_{\lambda}\right)$ can be written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\mu_{0}(E)^{2}}{\mu_{0}(E)+\int_{E}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}} \\
& \geq \frac{\mu_{0}(E)^{2}+2 \lambda \mu_{0}(E) H(E)+\lambda^{2} H(E)^{2}}{\mu_{0}(E)+\lambda H(E)+\int_{E}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}+\lambda[\cdots]+\lambda^{2}[\cdots]+\lambda^{3}[\cdots]}
\end{aligned}
$$

or equivalently

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda\left\{\mu_{0}(E)^{2}\left(-H(E)\right.\right. & \left.+\int_{E}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} H+2 \int_{E} \mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right) \mathrm{d} H\right) \\
& \left.-2 \mu_{0}(E) H(E) \int_{E}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}\right\}+\lambda^{2}[\cdots]+\lambda^{3} \int_{E}(\mathcal{S} H)^{2} \mathrm{~d} H \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Assume that $\lambda>0$ and divide both sides of the previous inequality by this factor and make $\lambda \rightarrow 0$ to obtain the desired estimate. Let us notice that the kernel associated to $\mathcal{S}$ is continuous, meaning that the terms in $[\cdots]$ and $\int_{E}(\mathcal{S} H)^{2} \mathrm{~d} H$ are finite, since $H(E)<\infty$ due to the fact that $\mu_{\lambda} \in \Sigma(E)$ for any $\lambda \in\left[0, \lambda_{0}\right]$ with $\lambda_{0}>0$.

We remark that in the particular case we will apply this lemma, $E$ will be a finite union of cubes, so $\mu_{0}(E)>0$. Moreover, we will choose a specific measure $H$ so that $H(E)>0$.

Therefore, in this setting, the inequality in Lemma 4.3 can be rewritten as

$$
\frac{\mu_{0}(E)+2 \int_{E}\left|\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}}{\mu_{0}(E)} \leq \frac{1}{H(E)} \int_{E}\left(\left|\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right|^{2}+2 \mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} H
$$

which is a similar estimate that resembles that of [Vo, Lemma 5.6].
We shall apply (4.1) to prove an auxiliary lemma, but first let us introduce the following notation for a certain maximal function applied to a measure:

$$
M \nu(\bar{x}):=\sup _{r>0} \frac{\nu\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right)}{r^{n}}
$$

Lemma 4.3. Let $E$ be a finite union of cubes. Then, for the potential

$$
\mathcal{U}^{\mu_{0}}:=M \mu_{0}+\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}+\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0}
$$

there is a constant $\alpha_{0}>0$ such that

$$
\mathcal{U}^{\mu_{0}}(\bar{x}) \geq \alpha_{0}, \quad \forall \bar{x} \in E
$$

Proof. Choose $\alpha_{1} \in\left(0,80^{-n}\right)$. If $\bar{x}_{0} \in E$ is such that $M \mu_{0}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \geq \alpha_{1}$ then we are done at $\bar{x}_{0}$. So assume $M \mu_{0}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)<\alpha_{1}$. Pick $\varepsilon_{1} \leq \tau_{0}, R_{0}:=\varepsilon_{1} / 10$ and $B_{0}:=B_{R_{0}}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$. Set $\mu_{00}:=\left.\mu_{0}\right|_{2 B_{0}}$ and define

$$
G:=\left\{\bar{y} \in B_{0} \cap E: M \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \leq 4^{-n}\right\}
$$

We shall prove that the complement of $G$ in $B_{0} \cap E$ is small. If $\bar{y} \in\left(B_{0} \cap E\right) \backslash G$, then there exists $r=r(\bar{y})>0$ so that

$$
\frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{y})\right)}{r^{n}}>4^{-n}
$$

If we had $r>\varepsilon_{1} / 20=R_{0} / 2$, then

$$
\frac{1}{80^{n}} \leq \frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{y})\right)}{20^{n} r^{n}} \leq \frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{20 r}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right)}{(20 r)^{n}}<\alpha_{1}, \quad \text { since } M \mu_{0}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)<\alpha_{1}
$$

and this cannot be. Then $r \leq \varepsilon_{1} / 20$, implying $B_{r}(\bar{y}) \cap\left(2 B_{0}\right)=B_{r}(\bar{y})$, which in turn implies $\mu_{00}\left(B_{r}(\bar{y})\right)=\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{y})\right)$. So we have found

$$
\forall \bar{y} \in\left(B_{0} \cap E\right) \backslash G, \exists r(\bar{y})>0 \text { such that } \frac{\mu_{00}\left(B_{r}(\bar{y})\right)}{r^{n}}>4^{-n}
$$

We continue by choosing $\varepsilon_{1}$ (that was already smaller than $\tau_{0}$ ) small enough so that

$$
\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{0} \cap E\right) \geq a(n) R_{0}^{n+1}=: a R_{0}^{n+1}
$$

for some dimensional constant $a>0$. This can be done since $E$ is a finite union of cubes. Notice also that the dependence on $E$ of the previous estimate is in $R_{0}$, since $\varepsilon_{1}$ depends on $\tau_{0}$, that depends on $E$. Using (4.2) and [Ma, Theorem 2.1] we obtain a countable covering $\left\{B_{5 r_{j}}\left(\bar{y}_{j}\right)\right\}$ of $\left(B_{0} \cap E\right) \backslash G$ with $\left\{B_{r_{j}}\left(\bar{y}_{j}\right)\right\}$ disjoint and also satisfying (4.2). Now,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(\left(B_{0} \cap E\right) \backslash G\right) & \leq 5^{n+1} \sum_{j} r_{j}^{n+1} \leq 2 \cdot 5^{n+1} R_{0} \sum_{j} r_{j}^{n} \\
& <10 \cdot 4^{n} \cdot 5^{n+1} R_{0} \sum_{j} \mu_{00}\left(B_{r_{j}}\left(\bar{y}_{j}\right)\right)=10 \cdot 20^{n} R_{0} \mu_{00}\left(\bigcup_{j} B_{r_{j}}\left(\bar{y}_{j}\right)\right) \\
& \leq 10 \cdot 20^{n} R_{0} \mu_{0}\left(2 B_{0}\right) \leq 10 \cdot 40^{n} R_{0}^{n+1} \alpha_{1}=: A(n) R_{0}^{n+1} \alpha_{1} \\
& \leq \frac{A}{a} \alpha_{1} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{0} \cap E\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have applied the hypothesis $M \mu_{0}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)<\alpha_{1}$. Therefore, by definition of $G$,

$$
\mathcal{L}^{n+1}(G) \geq\left(\frac{a}{A \alpha_{1}}-1\right) \mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(\left(B_{0} \cap E\right) \backslash G\right)
$$

We pick $\alpha_{1} \in\left(0,80^{-n}\right)$ depending only on $n$ so that

$$
\mathcal{L}^{n+1}(G):=\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(\left\{\bar{y} \in B_{0} \cap E: M \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \leq 4^{-n}\right\}\right)>0
$$

We will now prove that for all sufficiently small $\lambda>0, \mu_{0}+\left.\lambda \mathcal{L}^{n+1}\right|_{G}$ belongs to $\Sigma(E)$, i.e.

$$
M\left(\left.\mu_{0}+\lambda \mathcal{L}^{n+1}\right|_{G}\right) \leq 1, \quad \text { on } E \text { if } \lambda \in\left(0, \lambda_{0}\right)
$$

Let us fix $\bar{z} \in E, r>0$ and write $\mu_{\lambda}:=\left.\mu_{0}+\lambda \mathcal{L}^{n+1}\right|_{G}$. Distinguish three cases: first, if $B_{r}(\bar{z}) \cap G=\varnothing$ then it is clear that

$$
\frac{\mu_{\lambda}\left(B_{r}(\bar{z})\right)}{r^{n}}=\frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{z})\right)}{r^{n}} \leq 1
$$

that is the desired estimate. If $B_{r}(\bar{z}) \cap G \neq \varnothing$ and $\bar{z} \in G$, then

$$
\frac{\mu_{\lambda}\left(B_{r}(\bar{z})\right)}{r^{n}}=\frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{z})\right)}{r^{n}}+\lambda \frac{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{r}(\bar{z}) \cap G\right)}{r^{n}} \leq \frac{1}{4^{n}}+\lambda \frac{\min \left\{r^{n+1}, R_{0}^{n+1}\right\}}{r^{n}}
$$

If $r \leq R_{0}$, then

$$
\frac{\mu_{\lambda}\left(B_{r}(\bar{z})\right)}{r^{n}} \leq \frac{1}{4^{n}}+\lambda r \leq \frac{1}{4^{n}}+\lambda R_{0}<1, \quad \text { for } \lambda \text { small enough. }
$$

If on the other hand $r>R_{0}$, we also have

$$
\frac{\mu_{\lambda}\left(B_{r}(\bar{z})\right)}{r^{n}} \leq \frac{1}{4^{n}}+\lambda \frac{R_{0}^{n+1}}{r^{n}} \leq \frac{1}{4^{n}}+\lambda R_{0}<1, \quad \text { for } \lambda \text { small enough. }
$$

Finally, for the third case, that is, if $B_{r}(\bar{z}) \cap G \neq \varnothing$ and $\bar{z} \notin G$, take $\bar{y} \in B_{r}(\bar{z}) \cap G$ so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\mu_{\lambda}\left(B_{r}(\bar{z})\right)}{r^{n}} & =\frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{z})\right)}{r^{n}}+\lambda \frac{\min \left\{r^{n+1}, R_{0}^{n+1}\right\}}{r^{n}} \leq 2^{n} \frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{2 r}(\bar{y})\right)}{(2 r)^{n}}+\lambda R_{0} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{2^{n}}+\left(2^{n}+1\right) \lambda R_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

where for the last inequality we have applied the reasoning of the second case. Hence, in general, we deduce that for $\lambda>0$ small enough, $\mu_{\lambda} \in \Sigma(E)$.
Now we argue as follows: choose $\varepsilon_{1}^{(k)} \leq \varepsilon_{1}$ a sequence converging to 0 . For each $k$ set $R_{0}^{(k)}:=\varepsilon_{1}^{(k)} / 10$ and build a set $G_{k}$ in $B_{R_{0}^{(k)}}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$ as above. Let $H_{k}:=\left.\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\right|_{G_{k}}$ and apply Lemma 4.2, or in this particular case (4.1), to get

$$
1 \leq \frac{\mu_{0}(E)+2 \int_{E}\left|\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}}{\mu_{0}(E)} \leq \frac{1}{H_{k}(E)} \int_{E}\left(\left|\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right|^{2}+2 \mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)\right) \mathrm{d} H_{k}
$$

Since the measures $H_{k} / H_{k}(E)$ converge weakly to a point mass probability measure at $\bar{x}_{0}$, by the continuity of the kernel associated to $\mathcal{S}$ we have

$$
1 \leq\left|\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right|^{2}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)+2 \mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \quad \rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{2} \leq\left|\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right|^{2}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)+\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)
$$

Therefore, either $\left|\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right|^{2}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \geq 1 / 4$ or $\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \geq 1 / 4$, so in any case we get

$$
\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)+\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \geq \frac{1}{4}
$$

by the nonnegativity of each term. Since this last estimate follows if $M \mu_{0}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$ is smaller than $\alpha_{1}$, chosen to depend only on $n$, setting $\alpha_{0}:=\min \left\{\alpha_{1}, 1 / 4\right\}$ the result follows.
4.1. The construction. Both of the above lemmas are enough to carry out the construction of the desired cubes in a similar way to [Vo, pp. 38-42]. Fix $E \subset B_{1}(0) \subset 2 Q_{0}$ compact consisting of a finite union of cubes, and define the auxiliary potential

$$
\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}^{\mu_{0}}(\bar{x}):=\mathcal{U}^{\mu_{0}}(\bar{x})+M\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x})
$$

Apply Lemma 4.3 to $E$ and obtain its corresponding constant $\alpha_{0}$, and pick $0<\beta \ll 1$ depending only on $n$, to be fixed later on, and set

$$
\mathcal{G}:=\left\{\bar{y} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}: \widetilde{\mathcal{U}}^{\mu_{0}}(\bar{y})>\beta \alpha_{0}\right\} \supset E
$$

Consider $\left\{Q_{j}\right\}_{j}$ a Whitney decomposition of $\mathcal{G}$ (see [St, pp. 167-169], for example), that is: a countable family of closed dyadic cubes with disjoint interiors that cover $\mathcal{G}$ and such that for some constant $A>0$,

- $20 Q_{j} \subset \mathcal{G}$ for each $j$,
- $\left(A Q_{j}\right) \cap \mathcal{G}^{c} \neq \varnothing$ for each $j$,
- The family $\left\{10 Q_{j}\right\}_{j}$ has bounded overlap. Moreover, if $10 Q_{j} \cap 10 Q_{i} \neq \varnothing$, then $\ell\left(Q_{j}\right) \approx \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)$
From those $Q_{j}$ satisfying $\frac{5}{4} Q_{j} \cap E \neq \varnothing$, choose a finite subcovering and enumerate them as $Q_{j_{1}}, \ldots, Q_{j_{N}}$. We shall check that

$$
\mathcal{Q}_{i}:=2 Q_{j_{i}}, \quad i=1, \ldots, N
$$

is the desired family of cubes that satisfies the properties in Theorem 4.1. It is clear that properties $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{1}}$ and $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{5}}$ are satisfied by construction, so we are only left to verify $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{2}}, \mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{3}}$ and $\mathbf{P}_{4}$. The first two will be checked for $\gamma_{\mathrm{xy},+}$ instead of $\widetilde{\gamma}_{+}$, which is enough due to the comparability of both capacities.

Proof of $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{2}}$ in Theorem 4.1. We shall prove that property $\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}^{\mu_{0}}(\bar{x}) \geq \beta \alpha_{0}$ on $\mathcal{F}$, implies

$$
\gamma_{\mathrm{xy}, \mathrm{op}}(\mathcal{F}) \leq \frac{C}{\beta \alpha_{0}} \mu_{0}(E)
$$

where $\mu_{0}$ is an extremal measure for $\gamma_{\text {var }}(E)$ and $C>0$ constant. If this is the case, we are done, since we have
$\gamma_{\mathrm{xy},+}(\mathcal{F}) \approx \gamma_{\mathrm{xy}, \mathrm{op}}(\mathcal{F}) \leq \frac{C}{\beta \alpha_{0}} \gamma_{\text {var }}(E) \leq \frac{C}{\beta \alpha_{0}} \gamma_{\mathrm{xy}, \psi_{\mathrm{rp}}, 2}(E) \leq \frac{C}{\beta \alpha_{0}} 2 C_{1} C_{2} \gamma_{\mathrm{xy}, \mathrm{op}}(E) \approx \gamma_{\mathrm{xy},+}(E)$,

where for the third estimate recall Remark 3.4 and the fact that relation (3.10) holds in general, and in the fourth inequality we have used the definition of $\tau_{0}$.
So let us choose $\mu$ admissible for $\gamma_{\text {sy,op }}(\mathcal{F})$ with $\gamma_{\text {sy,op }}(\mathcal{F}) \leq 2 \mu(\mathcal{F})$ and observe that

$$
\left\|\mathcal{S}_{\mu}\right\|_{L^{2}(\mu) \rightarrow L^{2}(\mu)} \leq\left\|\mathcal{P}_{\mathrm{sy}, \mu}\right\|_{L^{2}(\mu) \rightarrow L^{2}(\mu)} \leq 1
$$

since $P_{\text {sy }}$ and the measure $\mu$ are nonnegative. Therefore, $\mathcal{S}_{\mu}$ becomes a C-Z convolution operator (with continuous kernel), so that it satisfies the weak estimate

$$
\mu\left(\left\{\mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \geq \lambda\right\}\right) \leq C^{\prime} \frac{\mu_{0}(E)}{\lambda}
$$

where $C^{\prime}>0$ is a constant. By definition, for each $\bar{x} \in \mathcal{F}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{\mathcal{H}}^{\mu_{0}}(\bar{x}) & :=M \mu_{0}(\bar{x})+\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}(\bar{x})+\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x})+M\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x}) \\
& =: \mathrm{I}(\bar{x})+\mathrm{II}(\bar{x})+\mathrm{III}(\bar{x})+\mathrm{IV}(\bar{x})
\end{aligned}
$$

so at least one of the four terms is larger than $\frac{\partial \mu_{0}}{4}=: a$. In fact, if we name

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{F}_{1}:=\{\bar{x} \in F: \mathrm{I}(\bar{x}) \geq a\}, & \mathcal{F}_{2}:=\{\bar{x} \in F: \mathrm{II}(\bar{x}) \geq a\}, \\
\mathcal{F}_{3}:=\{\bar{x} \in F: \mathrm{III}(\bar{x}) \geq a\}, & \mathcal{F}_{4}:=\{\bar{x} \in F: \mathrm{IV}(\bar{x}) \geq a\},
\end{aligned}
$$

we have $\mathcal{F}=\cup_{i=1}^{4} \mathcal{F}_{i}$. So in particular $\mu(\mathcal{F}) \leq \sum_{i=1}^{4} \mu\left(\mathcal{F}_{i}\right)$ and then, necessarily, there exists $i \in\{1,2,3,4\}$ such that $\mu\left(\mathcal{F}_{i}\right) \geq \mu(\mathcal{F}) / 4$. Let us study separately each possibility:
a) If $i=1$. In this case $M \mu_{0} \geq a$ on $\mathcal{F}_{1}$ with $\mu\left(\mathcal{F}_{1}\right) \geq \mu(\mathcal{F}) / 4$. For each $\bar{x} \in$ $\mathcal{F}_{1}$ choose a ball $B_{\bar{x}}:=B_{r(\bar{x})}(\bar{x})$ so that $\mu_{0}\left(B_{\bar{x}}\right) \geq a r(\bar{x})^{n}$. Apply Besicovitch's covering theorem [Ma, Theorem 2.7] to extract a countable collection of balls $\left\{B_{\bar{x}_{j}}\right\}_{j}$ with bounded multiplicity of overlapping (with constant depending only on the dimension) that covers $\mathcal{F}_{1}$. Then,

$$
\frac{\mu(\mathcal{F})}{4} \leq \mu\left(\mathcal{F}_{1}\right) \leq \sum_{j} \mu\left(B_{\bar{x}_{j}}\right) \leq \sum_{j} r^{n}\left(\bar{x}_{j}\right) \leq \frac{1}{a} \sum_{j} \mu_{0}\left(B_{\bar{x}_{j}}\right) \lesssim \frac{\mu_{0}\left(\mathcal{F}_{1}\right)}{a} \leq \frac{\mu_{0}(E)}{a}
$$

since $\mu_{0}$ is supported on $E$.
b) If $i=2$. Now $\mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \geq a$ on $\mathcal{F}_{2}$ with $\mu\left(\mathcal{F}_{2}\right) \geq \mu(\mathcal{F}) / 4$. Using the weak estimate presented above we get the desired estimate

$$
\frac{\mu(\mathcal{F})}{4} \leq \mu\left(\mathcal{F}_{2}\right)=\mu\left(\left\{\mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \geq a\right\}\right) \leq \frac{C^{\prime}}{a} \mu_{0}(E)
$$

c) If $i=3$. Now $\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right) \geq a$ on $\mathcal{F}_{3}$ with $\mu\left(\mathcal{F}_{3}\right) \geq \mu(\mathcal{F}) / 4$. By (3.10) we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\mu(\mathcal{F})}{4} \leq \mu\left(\mathcal{F}_{3}\right) & =\mu\left(\left\{\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right) \geq a\right\}\right) \leq \frac{C^{\prime}}{a} \int_{E} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0} \\
& \leq \frac{C^{\prime}}{a} \mu_{0}(E)^{1 / 2}\left(\int_{E}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}\right)^{2} \leq \frac{C^{\prime}}{a} \mu_{0}(E)
\end{aligned}
$$

d) If $i=4$. Now $M\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}\right) \geq a$ on $\mathcal{F}_{4}$ with $\mu\left(\mathcal{F}_{4}\right) \geq \mu(\mathcal{F}) / 4$. Proceeding analogously as in the first case, we deduce

$$
\frac{\mu(\mathcal{F})}{4} \lesssim \frac{1}{a} \int_{E} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}
$$

and arguing as in the third case we obtain the desired result.

To prove $\mathbf{P}_{3}$ we will need the following lemma:

Lemma 4.4. For $i=1, \ldots, N$ define $\mu_{i}:=\left.\mu_{0}\right|_{5 Q_{j_{i}}}$ and consider the auxiliary potential

$$
\mathcal{W}^{\mu_{i}}:=M \mu_{i}+\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{i}} 1+\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{i}}\left(\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\right)+M\left(\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{i}\right)
$$

Then, there exists a constant $\alpha_{0}^{\prime}>0$ such that for each $i=1, \ldots, N$,

$$
\mathcal{W}^{\mu_{i}}(\bar{x}) \geq \alpha_{0}^{\prime} \alpha_{0}, \quad \forall \bar{x} \in 4 Q_{j_{i}} \cap E
$$

Proof. For the sake of notation, in this proof we rename $Q_{i}:=Q_{j_{i}}$. Fix $i=1, \ldots, N$, $\bar{x} \in 4 Q_{i} \cap E$ and $\bar{z} \in\left(A Q_{i}\right) \cap \mathcal{G}^{c}$, which is non-empty by construction. So in particular

$$
M \mu_{0}(\bar{z}) \leq \beta \alpha_{0}, \quad \mathcal{S} \mu_{0}(\bar{z}) \leq \beta \alpha_{0}
$$

Now choosing, for example, $R:=2(4+A) \operatorname{diam}\left(Q_{i}\right)$ it is clear that we have

$$
|\bar{x}-\bar{z}| \leq(4+A) \operatorname{diam}\left(Q_{i}\right) \leq \frac{R}{2}
$$

Therefore, using the C-Z estimates for $P_{\mathrm{xy}} \psi_{\tau_{0}}$, the nonnegativity of the latter kernel and relations (4.3) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{S}_{R} \mu_{0}(\bar{x}) & :=\int_{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|>R} P_{\mathrm{xy}}(\bar{x}-\bar{y}) \psi_{\tau_{0}}(\bar{x}-\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \\
& \leq \beta \alpha_{0}+\int_{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|>R}\left|P_{\mathrm{xy}}(\bar{x}-\bar{y}) \psi_{\tau_{0}}(\bar{x}-\bar{y})-P_{\mathrm{xy}}(\bar{z}-\bar{y}) \psi_{\tau_{0}}(\bar{z}-\bar{y})\right| \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \\
& \lesssim \beta \alpha_{0}+|\bar{x}-\bar{z}| \int_{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|>R} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n+1}} \lesssim \beta \alpha_{0}+|\bar{x}-\bar{z}| \int_{|\bar{z}-\bar{y}|>R / 4} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{z}-\bar{y}|^{n+1}} \\
& \leq \beta \alpha_{0}+\frac{R}{2} \sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{2^{j+1} R}(\bar{z})\right)}{(2^{j} R)^{n+1}} \leq \beta \alpha_{0}+\frac{R}{2} \sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \frac{\beta \alpha_{0}\left(2^{j+1} R\right)^{n}}{(2^{j} R)^{n+1}} \lesssim \beta \alpha_{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

We also notice that there exists $\widetilde{A}=\widetilde{A}(n)>0$ such that

$$
M \mu_{0}(\bar{x}) \leq \max \left\{\widetilde{A} \beta \alpha_{0}, M \mu_{i}(\bar{x})\right\}
$$

Indeed, if $r \geq \ell\left(Q_{i}\right) / 20$ then

$$
\frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right)}{r^{n}} \leq \frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{40 \sqrt{n} A r}(\bar{z})\right)}{r^{n}} \leq \widetilde{A}(n) \beta \alpha_{0}
$$

If $r<\ell\left(Q_{i}\right) / 20$ use that $\bar{x} \in 4 Q_{i}$ and $\mu_{i}:=\left.\mu_{0}\right|_{5 Q_{i}}$ to simply have

$$
\frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right)}{r^{n}}=\frac{\mu_{j}\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right)}{r^{n}}
$$

so indeed $M \mu_{0}(\bar{x}) \leq \max \left\{\widetilde{A} \beta \alpha_{0}, M \mu_{i}(\bar{x})\right\}$. Having made this observations, we recall that by Lemma 4.3 we always have

$$
M \mu_{0}+\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}+\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right) \geq \alpha_{0}, \quad \text { on } E
$$

Now we distinguish three cases:

a) If $M \mu_{0}(\bar{x}) \geq \alpha_{0} / 3$. Then (4.5) implies

$$
\frac{\alpha_{0}}{3} \leq \max \left\{\widetilde{A} \beta \alpha_{0}, M \mu_{i}(\bar{x})\right\}
$$

so choosing $\beta \leq(6 \widetilde{A})^{-1}$ we deduce $M \mu_{i}(\bar{x}) \geq \alpha_{0} / 6$ and we would be done.
b) If $\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}(\bar{x}) \geq \alpha_{0} / 3$, by (4.4) there exists $C>0$ constant such that

$$
\left.\mathcal{S}\left(\left.\mu\right|_{B_{R}(\bar{x})}\right)(\bar{x}) \geq \frac{\alpha_{0}}{3}-C \beta \alpha_{0} \geq \frac{\alpha_{0}}{4}
$$

for $\beta$ small enough. In addition, by definition of $R$,

$$
\left.\mathcal{S}\left(\left.\mu\right|_{B_{R}(\bar{x}) \backslash 5 Q_{i}}\right)(\bar{x}) \leq C^{\prime} \frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{2 R}(\bar{z})\right)}{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)^{n}} \leq 2^{n} C^{\prime} \beta \alpha_{0} \frac{R^{n}}{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)^{n}}=C^{\prime \prime} \beta \alpha_{0}
$$

Hence

$$
\left.\mathcal{S} \mu_{i}(\bar{x})=\left.\mathcal{S}\left(\left.\mu_{0}\right|_{5 Q_{i}}\right)(\bar{x}) \geq \frac{\alpha_{0}}{4}-C^{\prime \prime} \beta \alpha_{0} \geq \frac{\alpha_{0}}{5}\right.
$$

for $\beta$ small enough, and we are done.
c) If $\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x}) \geq \alpha_{0} / 3$. Let us observe that for $\bar{z} \in\left(A Q_{i}\right) \cap \mathcal{G}^{c}$, by definition of $\mathcal{G}$ we also have

$$
M\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{z}) \leq \beta \alpha_{0}, \quad \mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{z}) \leq \beta \alpha_{0}
$$

So choosing again $R:=2(4+A) \operatorname{diam}\left(Q_{i}\right)$ we would be able to prove analogously as in (4.4) that

$$
\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}, R}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x}) \leq C \beta \alpha_{0}
$$

for some $C>0$ constant. Moreover,

$$
\left.\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\right|_{B_{R}(\bar{x}) \backslash 5 Q_{i}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x}) \leq C^{\prime} \frac{\int_{B_{2 R}(\bar{z})} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}}{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)^{n}} \leq C^{\prime \prime} \beta \alpha_{0}
$$

where we have used, again, the definition of $R$ and that $M\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{z}) \leq \beta \alpha_{0}$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{i}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x}) & =\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x})-\mathcal{S}_{\left.\mu_{0}\right|_{B_{R}(\bar{x}) \backslash 5 Q_{i}}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x})-\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}, R}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x}) \\
& \geq \frac{\alpha_{0}}{3}-C^{\prime \prime} \beta \alpha_{0}-C \beta \alpha_{0} \geq \frac{\alpha_{0}}{5}
\end{aligned}
$$

for $\beta$ small enough, and the proof is completed.

Proof of $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{3}}$ in Theorem 4.1. Repeating the same arguments presented for the proof of $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{2}}$, one deduces that property $\mathcal{W}^{\mu_{i}}(\bar{x}) \geq \alpha_{0}^{\prime} \alpha$, for every $\bar{x} \in 4 Q_{j_{i}} \cap E$ and every $i=1, \ldots, N$, implies

$$
\gamma_{\mathrm{xy}, \mathrm{op}}\left(4 Q_{j_{i}} \cap E\right) \leq \frac{C}{\alpha_{0}^{\prime} \alpha_{0}}\left(\mu_{0}\left(5 Q_{j_{i}}\right)+\int_{5 Q_{j_{i}}} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}\right)
$$

But notice that the bounded multiplicity of overlapping of the family $\left\{10 Q_{j}\right\}_{j}$ and the fact that $\mu_{0}$ is supported on $E$ yield

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\mu_{0}\left(Q_{j_{i}}\right)+\int_{5 Q_{j_{i}}} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0}\right) \lesssim \mu_{0}(E)+\int_{E} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0} \mathrm{~d} \mu_{0} \leq 2 \mu_{0}(E)
$$

where for the last inequality we have used (3.10). Therefore, by the latter relation and using the definition of $\tau_{0}$ we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i=1}^{N} \gamma_{\mathrm{xy},+}\left(4 Q_{j_{i}} \cap E\right) & \lesssim \sum_{i=1}^{N} \gamma_{\mathrm{xy}, \mathrm{op}}\left(4 Q_{j_{i}} \cap E\right) \lesssim \mu_{0}(E) \\
& =\gamma_{\mathrm{var}}(E) \leq \gamma_{\mathrm{xy}, \psi_{\tau_{0}}, 2}(E) \leq 2 C_{1} C_{2} \gamma_{\mathrm{xy}, \mathrm{op}}(E) \lesssim \gamma_{\mathrm{xy},+}(E)
\end{aligned}
$$

that is the desired estimate.
Finally, we prove $\mathbf{P}_{4}$. Let us first observe that the assumption

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E) \leq C_{+} \operatorname{diam}(E)^{n}, \quad \text { for } C_{+}>0 \text { constant to be fixed below, }
$$

is not at all restrictive. Indeed, if it failed, [MPr, Lemma 4.1] would imply

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \leq \gamma(E) \lesssim \mathcal{H}_{\infty}^{n}(E) \leq \operatorname{diam}(E)^{n}<\frac{1}{C_{+}} \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E)
$$

and we would be done.
Proof of $\mathbf{P}_{4}$ in Theorem 4.1. Fix $\bar{x} \notin E$ and observe that the following estimates hold

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}(\bar{x}) & \leq \frac{\mu_{0}(E)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)^{n}} \\
\mathcal{S}_{\mu_{0}}\left(\mathcal{S} \mu_{0}\right)(\bar{x}) & \leq \frac{1}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)^{n}} \int_{E} \int_{E} P_{\mathrm{xy}}(\bar{y}-\bar{z}) \psi_{\tau_{0}}(\bar{y}-\bar{z}) \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{z}) \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \\
& =\frac{1}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)^{n}} \int_{E} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \leq \frac{\mu_{0}(E)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)^{n}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where for the last inequality we have applied (3.10). Since $\operatorname{supp}\left(\mu_{0}\right) \subset E$, we have

$$
\sup _{r>0} \frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right)}{r^{n}}=\sup _{r>\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)} \frac{\mu_{0}\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right)}{r^{n}} \leq \frac{\mu_{0}(E)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)^{n}}
$$

and moreover, due to (3.10) again,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{r>0} \frac{1}{r^{n}} \int_{B_{r}(\bar{x})} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) & =\sup _{r>\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)} \frac{1}{r^{n}} \int_{B_{r}(\bar{x})} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)^{n}} \int_{E} \mathcal{S} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu_{0}(\bar{y}) \leq \frac{\mu_{0}(E)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)^{n}}
\end{aligned}
$$

All in all, we get

$$
\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}^{\mu_{0}}(\bar{x}) \leq \frac{4 \mu_{0}(E)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)}
$$

Let us pick $\bar{x} \in \mathcal{G} \cap E^{c}$ (which is non empty, since $E \subset \mathcal{G}$ with $\mathcal{G}$ open, by the lower semicontinuity of the potential $\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}^{\mu_{0}}$ ) so that $\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}^{\mu_{0}}(\bar{x})>\beta \alpha_{0}$ and observe that using the definition of $\mu_{0}$ and $\tau_{0}$ as in the previous proofs, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, E)^{n} & \leq \frac{8 C_{1} C_{2}}{\alpha_{0} \beta} \gamma_{\mathrm{xy}, \mathrm{op}}(E) \leq \frac{8 C C_{1} C_{2}}{\alpha_{0} \beta} \gamma_{\mathrm{xy},+}(E) \\
& \leq \frac{16 C C_{1} C_{2}}{\alpha_{0} \beta} \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E) \leq \frac{16 C C_{1} C_{2}}{\alpha_{0} \beta} C_{+} \operatorname{diam}(E)^{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Choosing $C_{+}$appropriately to neglect the effect of all the above constants that have already been fixed, the result follows. Indeed, this is because the previous estimate is valid for all

$\bar{x} \in \mathcal{G} \cap E^{c}$, implying that one can make $\partial \mathcal{G}$ say $\frac{\operatorname{diam}(E)}{1000}$ close to $E$. Since we also know that $20 Q_{j} \subset \mathcal{G}$ we have

$$
\operatorname{diam}\left(2 Q_{j}\right) \leq \frac{1}{10} \operatorname{dist}\left(\partial \mathcal{G}, Q_{j}\right)
$$

where $\operatorname{dist}\left(\partial \mathcal{G}, Q_{j}\right)$ is comparable to $\operatorname{dist}(\partial \mathcal{G}, E)$ since the cubes $Q_{j}$ have been also chosen so that $\frac{5}{4} Q_{j} \cap E \neq \varnothing$.

# 5. A comparability Result under an additional assumption 

Let $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a compact set. As it is stated in $\mathbf{P}_{4}$ in Theorem 4.1, we shall work under the following additional assumption:

$$
\mathbf{A}_{1}: \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E) \leq C_{+} \operatorname{diam}(E)^{n} \text {, with } C_{+}>0 \text { constant. }
$$

By the translation invariance and $\widetilde{\gamma}(\lambda E)=\lambda^{n} \widetilde{\gamma}(E), \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(\lambda E)=\lambda^{n} \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E)$ (see [He, Proposition 3.1]), it is clear that we may assume $E \subset B_{1}(0)$ without loss of generality. In fact, in order to apply Theorem 4.1 let us check that we can assume:
$\mathbf{A}_{2}: E$ is contained in the unit ball and consists of a finite union of dyadic cubes belonging to a dyadic grid in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ (with sides parallel to the coordinate axes), all with the same size and with disjoint interiors.

Let us verify that if we deduce the comparability between $\widetilde{\gamma}$ and $\widetilde{\gamma}_{+}$for $E$ satisfying $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{2}}$, we obtain the same result for a general $E$. So fix $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ any compact set and let $\overline{\mathcal{U}_{\delta}(E)}$ be the closed $\delta$-neighbourhood of $E$. Consider a grid of dyadic cubes in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ with sides parallel to the axes and diameter smaller than $\delta / 2$. Name $E_{0}$ the collection of dyadic cubes that intersect $E$ and notice that $E \subset E_{0} \subset \overline{\mathcal{U}_{\delta}(E)}$. Now we would have

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \leq \widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{0}\right) \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(E_{0}\right) \leq \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(\overline{\mathcal{U}_{\delta}(E)}\right) \leq \gamma_{+}\left(\overline{\mathcal{U}_{\delta}(E)}\right)
$$

Letting $\delta \rightarrow 0$ and using the outer regularity of $\gamma_{+}$we deduce, by Theorem 3.5,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \lesssim \gamma_{+}(E) \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E)
$$

and the result follows.
Finally, we present the final additional assumption that motivates the title of this section:
$\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{3}}$. Let $\left\{\mathcal{Q}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{Q}_{N}\right\}$ be the family of cubes provided by Theorem 4.1 and $C_{1}$ the constant appearing in point $\mathbf{P}_{\mathbf{3}}$ of the same theorem. We will assume that

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \geq C_{1}^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 \mathcal{Q}_{i} \cap E\right)
$$

The aim of this section is to prove the comparability between $\widetilde{\gamma}$ and $\widetilde{\gamma}_{+}$under assumption $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{3}}$. Later on, we will get rid of these hypotheses in some particular cases, for which we will obtain the desired comparability in full generality.

5.1. Basic definitions and properties. Let $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a compact set verifying $\mathbf{A}_{1}, \mathbf{A}_{2}$ and $\mathbf{A}_{3}$. We begin our argument by fixing a distribution $T_{0}$ admissible for $\widetilde{\gamma}(E)$ so that $\left|\left\langle T_{0}, 1\right\rangle\right|=\widetilde{\gamma}(E) / 2$. We know that $T_{0}$ has $n$-growth with constant 1 and

$$
\left\|P * T_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1, \quad\left\|P^{*} * T_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1
$$

Let $\mathcal{F}:=\cup_{i=1}^{N} \mathcal{Q}_{i}$ be the covering by cubes provided by Theorem 4.1. Recall that $\mathcal{Q}_{i}=2 Q_{i}$, where $\left\{Q_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ is the finite subset of dyadic cubes with disjoint interiors of a Whitney decomposition of $\mathcal{G} \supset E$, with the property $\frac{5}{4} Q_{i} \cap E \neq \varnothing$. We write

$$
F:=\bigcup_{i=1}^{N} Q_{i} \subset \mathcal{F}
$$

It is clear that $E \subset F$ and moreover, by monotonicity and the properties in Theorem 4.1 we also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{P}_{2}^{\prime} \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(F) \leq C_{0} \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E) \\
& \mathbf{P}_{3}^{\prime} \cdot \sum_{i=1}^{N} \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \leq C_{1} \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E) \text { and by } \mathbf{A}_{3} \text { we also have } \sum_{i=1}^{N} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \leq C_{1} \widetilde{\gamma}(E) \\
& \mathbf{P}_{4}^{\prime} \operatorname{diam}\left(Q_{i}\right) \leq \frac{1}{20} \operatorname{diam}(E), \text { for each } i=1, \ldots, N \\
& \mathbf{P}_{5}^{\prime} \text {. The family }\left\{10 Q_{1}, \ldots, 10 Q_{N}\right\} \text { has bounded overlap. Moreover, if } 10 Q_{j} \cap 10 Q_{i} \neq \varnothing, \\
& \text { then } \ell\left(Q_{j}\right) \approx \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In order to simplify the arguments, in this section we will work with the cubes $Q_{1}, \ldots, Q_{N}$ instead of $\mathcal{Q}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{Q}_{N}$, and with $F$ instead of $\mathcal{F}$. Let us choose for each $Q_{i}$ a ball $B_{i} \subset \frac{1}{2} Q_{i}$ concentric with $Q_{i}$ with radius $r_{i}$ comparable to $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)^{1 / n}$. Notice that

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)^{1 / n} \leq \gamma\left(2 Q_{i}\right)^{1 / n} \approx \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)
$$

Therefore, we may choose $r_{i} \approx \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)^{1 / n}$ with constants depending at most on the dimension and still have $B_{i} \subset \frac{1}{2} Q_{i}$. Notice that $\operatorname{dist}\left(B_{i}, B_{j}\right) \geq \frac{1}{2} \min \left\{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right), \ell\left(Q_{j}\right)\right\}$, for $i \neq j$. We define the positive measure

$$
\mu:=\sum_{i=1}^{N} \mu_{i}:=\sum_{i=1}^{N} \frac{r_{i}^{n}}{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{i}\right)} \mathcal{L}^{n+1} \|_{B_{i}} .
$$

Apply [HPo, Lemma 3.1] to pick test functions $\varphi_{i} \in \mathcal{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(2 Q_{i}\right), 0 \leq \varphi_{i} \leq 1$, satisfying $\left\|\nabla \varphi_{i}\right\|_{\infty} \leq \ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right)^{-1}$ and with $\sum_{i=1}^{N} \varphi_{i} \equiv 1$ in $F$. We also define the signed measure

$$
\nu:=\sum_{i=1}^{N} \frac{\left\langle T_{0}, \varphi_{i}\right\rangle}{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{i}\right)} \mathcal{L}^{n+1} \|_{B_{i}}, \quad \text { that is } \quad \nu=\sum_{i=1}^{N} \frac{\left\langle T_{0}, \varphi_{i}\right\rangle}{r_{i}^{n}} \mu_{i}
$$

Since $\operatorname{supp}(\nu) \subset \operatorname{supp}(\mu) \subset \mathcal{F}$ and $\nu \ll \mu$, have $\nu=b \mu$, where $b$ is the Radon-Nikodym derivative.

Lemma 5.1. The following hold for some positive constants $c_{1}, c_{3}$ and $c_{4}$ :

1. $\|b\|_{\infty} \leq c_{1}$.
2. $|\nu(F)|=\widetilde{\gamma}(E) / 2$.
3. $\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \leq c_{3} \mu(F)$.
4. $|\nu(Q)| \leq c_{4} \ell(Q)^{n}$ for any cube $Q \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$.

Proof. Let us prove 1. By the localization result [MPr, Theorem 3.1] we get $\left\|P *\left(\varphi_{i} T_{0}\right)\right\|_{\infty} \leq$ $A_{1}$, for every $i$, where $A_{1}=A_{1}(n)>0$. Analogously, the same localization result holds for $P^{*}$, so there also exists $A_{2}=A_{2}(n)>0$ with $\left\|P^{*}\left(\varphi_{i} T_{0}\right)\right\|_{\infty} \leq A_{2}, \forall i$. Therefore, since $\operatorname{supp}\left(\varphi_{i} T_{0}\right) \subset 2 Q_{i} \cap E$ we have

$$
\left|\left\langle T_{0}, \varphi_{i}\right\rangle\right|=\left|\left\langle\varphi_{i} T_{0}, 1\right\rangle\right| \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \approx r_{i}^{n}, \quad \forall i=1, \ldots, n
$$

which yields the desired result.
To prove 2 we simply use the definition of $\nu, B_{i} \cap F=B_{i}$ and $\operatorname{supp}\left(T_{0}\right) \subset E \subset F$ :

$$
|\nu(F)|=\left|\sum_{i=1}^{N} \frac{\left\langle T_{0}, \varphi_{i}\right\rangle}{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{i}\right)} \int_{B_{i}} \mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}\right|=\left|\left\langle T_{0}, \sum_{i=1}^{N} \varphi_{i}\right\rangle\right|=\left|\left\langle T_{0}, 1\right\rangle\right|=\frac{1}{2} \widetilde{\gamma}(E)
$$

Finally, 3 follows by the choice of radii $r_{i}$ and the admissibility of $\varphi_{i} T_{0}$ for $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)$,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E)=2\left|\left\langle T_{0}, 1\right\rangle\right| \leq 2 \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left|\left\langle T_{0}, \varphi_{i}\right\rangle\right| \lesssim \sum_{i=1}^{N} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \approx \sum_{i=1}^{N} r_{i}^{n}=\mu(F)
$$

The proof of inequality 4 can be followed analogously to that given for property $(g)$ of [To3, Lemma 6.8]. We refer the reader to this last reference for the detailed arguments.

Remark 5.1. In the proof of inequality 4 it is used that for a Borel signed measure $\nu$ satisfying $\left\|P * \nu\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ one has $|\nu(Q)| \leq C \ell(Q)^{n}$, for some constant $C>0$ and any cube $Q \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. In order to justify that this holds in our context we will prove the following: given $\varphi \in \mathcal{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$ such that $\|P * \varphi\|_{\infty} \leq 1$, then $\left|\int_{Q} \varphi \mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}\right| \leq C \ell(Q)^{n}$, for some $C>0$ constant. If this is the case, we will be done by mollifying $\nu$ to be $\nu_{\varepsilon}:=\nu * \psi_{\varepsilon}$ with $\left(\psi_{\varepsilon}\right)_{\varepsilon}$ a proper approximation of the identity. Let us estimate $\left|\int_{Q} \varphi \mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}\right|$ as follows:

$$
\left|\int_{Q} \varphi(\bar{x}) \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x})\right| \leq\left|\int_{Q} \partial_{t}(P * \varphi)(\bar{x}) \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x})\right|+\left|\int_{Q}\left(\Delta_{x}\right)^{1 / 2}(P * \varphi)(\bar{x}) \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x})\right|
$$

For the first term of the right-hand side we set $Q=Q_{1} \times I_{Q} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \times \mathbb{R}$ where $I_{Q}$ is the temporal interval, that we write as $I_{Q}=[a, b]$ for some $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$ with $a<b$. This way, by Fubini's theorem,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\int_{Q} \partial_{t}(P * \varphi)(\bar{x}) \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x})\right| & =\left|\int_{Q_{1}}\left(\int_{a}^{b} \partial_{t}(P * \varphi)(x, t) \mathrm{d} t\right) \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n}(x)\right| \\
& =\left|\int_{Q_{1}}(P * \varphi(x, b)-P * \varphi(x, a)) \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n}(x)\right| \\
& \lesssim\|P * \varphi\|_{\infty} \mathcal{L}^{n}\left(Q_{1}\right) \leq \ell(Q)^{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the second term we recall that we have the following representation

$$
\left(\Delta_{x}\right)^{1 / 2} \approx \sum_{j=1}^{n} \partial_{j} R_{j}
$$

where $R_{j}, 1 \leq j \leq n$ are the Riesz transforms with Fourier multiplier $\xi_{j} /\left|\xi_{j}\right|$. Notice that if we prove that $P *\left(R_{j} \varphi\right) \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$ for each $j=1, \ldots, n$, we are done, since we may argue as above decomposing the cube $Q$ as a cartesian product of an interval and an $n$-dimensional cube. To study $P *\left(R_{j} \varphi\right)$ we consider its Fourier transform $\frac{\xi_{j}}{|\xi|} \widehat{P} \widehat{\varphi}$. Notice that $P \in\left(L^{1}+L^{2}\right)\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$ (just decompose it as $P \chi_{|\bar{x}| \leq 1}+P \chi_{|\bar{x}|>1}$ ), and therefore $\widehat{P} \in\left(L^{\infty}+L^{2}\right)\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$, and we write its decomposition as $\widehat{P}_{\infty}+\widehat{P}_{2}$. Now it is immediate

to check that $\frac{\xi_{i}}{|\xi|} \widehat{P}_{\infty} \widehat{\varphi} \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$ and we also have $\frac{\xi_{i}}{|\xi|} \widehat{P}_{2} \widehat{\varphi} \in L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$ using CauchySchwarz inequality. Therefore the Fourier transform of $P *\left(R_{j} \varphi\right)$ is integrable, implying $P *\left(R_{j} \varphi\right) \in L^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$ that is what we wanted to see.
5.2. The exceptional sets $\boldsymbol{H}_{\mathcal{D}}$ and $\boldsymbol{T}_{\mathcal{D}}$. In light of the third property in Lemma 5.1, assume we find a compact set $G \subset F$ such that
i. $\mu(F) \lesssim \mu(G)$,
ii. $\left.\mu\right|_{G}$ has $n$-growth,
iii. $\left.\mathcal{P}_{\mu}\right|_{G}$ is a bounded operator in $L^{2}\left(\left.\mu\right|_{G}\right)$.

Then, $\left.\left.\mu\right|_{G}\right.$ is admissible for $\gamma_{\text {op }}(G)$, and we are done, since we have

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \lesssim \mu(F) \lesssim \mu(G) \leq \gamma_{\text {op }}(G) \leq \gamma_{\text {op }}(F) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(F) \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E)
$$

where the first inequality is due to Lemma 5.1 and the last is by property $\mathbf{P}_{2}^{\prime}$ above.
The construction of $G$ is inspired by the $T b$-theorems found in [To3, Theorem 5.1] and [Vo, Theorem 7.1], which are presented for the particular case of Cauchy and Riesz potentials respectively. To apply this kind of results we need to introduce the notions of Ahlfors ball, Ahlfors radius and Ahlfors point in our context. Due to [MPr, Lemma 4.1] there are positive dimensional constants $a_{1}, a_{2}$ such that

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \leq a_{1} \operatorname{diam}(E)^{n}
$$

and also

$$
a_{2}^{-1} r_{i}^{n} \leq \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \leq a_{2} r_{i}^{n}
$$

for each $i=1, \ldots, N$, where $r_{i}$ is the radius of the ball $B_{i} \subset Q_{i}$ constructed at the beginning of Subsection 5.1. Let

$$
L:=100^{n} a_{1} a_{2} C_{1}
$$

where $C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ are the constants appearing in Theorem 4.1. The factor 100 is arbitrarily chosen; we may pick, for convenience, any other large constant. Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ implies

$$
\mu(F)=\sum_{i=1}^{N} r_{i}^{n} \leq a_{2} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \leq a_{2} C_{1} \widetilde{\gamma}(E) \leq a_{1} a_{2} C_{1} \operatorname{diam}(E)^{n}
$$

Therefore:

$$
\forall \bar{x} \in F, \forall R>\frac{1}{100} \operatorname{diam}(F): \quad \mu\left(B_{R}(\bar{x})\right) \leq L R^{n}
$$

A ball $B_{R}(\bar{x}), \bar{x} \in F$, is an Ahlfors ball if precisely the estimate $\mu\left(B_{R}(\bar{x})\right) \leq L R^{n}$ holds. Notice that if $R>\frac{1}{100} \operatorname{diam}(F)$, then the ball is an Ahlfors ball. We also define the Ahlfors radius,

$$
\mathcal{R}(\bar{x}):=\sup \left\{r>0: B_{r}(\bar{x}) \text { is non-Ahlfors }\right\}
$$

Ahlfors points are those for which $\mathcal{R}(\bar{x})=0$. For every $\bar{x} \in F$, we have $\mathcal{R}(\bar{x}) \leq$ $\frac{1}{100} \operatorname{diam}(F)$. Set

$$
H^{\prime}:=\bigcup_{\bar{x} \in F} B_{\mathcal{R}(\bar{x})}(\bar{x})
$$

where we convey $B_{0}(\bar{x}):=\varnothing$, and apply a $5 r$-covering theorem [Ma, Theorem 2.1] to choose a countable family of disjoint balls $\left\{B_{\mathcal{R}_{k}}\right\}_{k}:=\left\{B_{\mathcal{R}\left(\bar{x}_{k}\right)}\left(\bar{x}_{k}\right)\right\}_{k}$ such that

$$
H^{\prime} \subset H:=\bigcup_{k} B_{5 \mathcal{R}_{k}}
$$

so that all non-Ahlfors balls are contained in $H$. Observe that since $\mu\left(B_{\mathcal{R}_{k}}\right) \geq L \mathcal{R}_{k}^{n}$ and the balls $B_{\mathcal{R}_{k}}$ are disjoint, we have

$$
\sum_{k} \mathcal{R}_{k}^{n} \leq \frac{1}{L} \sum_{k} \mu\left(B_{\mathcal{R}_{k}}\right) \leq \frac{1}{L} \mu(F)
$$

Let $\mathcal{D}^{0}$ be the usual dyadic lattice in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and for $\bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ we write

$$
\mathcal{D}(\bar{x}):=\bar{x}+\mathcal{D}^{0}
$$

the translation of $\mathcal{D}^{0}$ by the vector $\bar{x}$. Let $\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})$ be any fixed dyadic lattice from the family of lattices $\{\mathcal{D}(\bar{y})\}_{\bar{y} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}}$. Consider the subcollection of dyadic cubes $\mathcal{D}_{H} \subset \mathcal{D}$ defined as follows: $Q \in \mathcal{D}_{H}$ if there is a ball $B_{5 \mathcal{R}_{k}}\left(\bar{x}_{k}\right)$ satisfying

$$
B_{5 \mathcal{R}_{k}}\left(\bar{x}_{k}\right) \cap Q \neq \varnothing \quad \text { and } \quad 10 \mathcal{R}_{k}<\ell(Q) \leq 20 \mathcal{R}_{k}
$$

Then, it is clear that

$$
\bigcup_{k} B_{5 \mathcal{R}_{k}}\left(\bar{x}_{k}\right) \subset \bigcup_{Q \in \mathcal{D}_{H}} Q
$$

Pick a subfamily of disjoint maximal cubes $\left\{Q_{k}\right\}_{k}$ from $\mathcal{D}_{H}$ so that we may define the exceptional set $H_{\mathcal{D}}$ as follows

$$
\bigcup_{Q \in \mathcal{D}_{H}} Q=\bigcup_{k} Q_{k}=: H_{\mathcal{D}}=H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})}
$$

By construction one has

$$
H \subset H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})}, \quad \forall \bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}
$$

and since for each ball $B_{5 \mathcal{R}_{k}}\left(\bar{x}_{k}\right)$ conditions (5.7) can only occur for a number of cubes in $\mathcal{D}_{H}$ which is bounded by a dimensional constant, there is $c_{H}=c_{H}(n)>0$ so that

$$
\sum_{k} \ell\left(Q_{k}\right)^{n} \leq c_{H} \sum_{k} \mathcal{R}_{k}^{n} \leq \frac{c_{H}}{L} \mu(F)
$$

We define the exceptional set $T_{\mathcal{D}}$ in a similar manner but imposing a proper accretivity condition on the Radon-Nikodym derivative $b$. Consider the family $\mathcal{D}_{T} \subset \mathcal{D}$ of cubes satisfying

$$
\mu(Q) \geq c_{T}|\nu(Q)|
$$

with $c_{T}=c_{T}(n)>0$ big constant to be fixed below. Let $\left\{Q_{k}\right\}_{k}$ be the subcollection of maximal (and thus disjoint) dyadic cubes from $\mathcal{D}_{T}$. We define the exceptional set $T_{\mathcal{D}}=T_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})}$ as

$$
T_{\mathcal{D}}:=\bigcup_{k} Q_{k}
$$

The next result shows that $\mu\left(F \backslash\left(H_{\mathcal{D}} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}}\right)\right)$ is comparable to $\mu(F)$. The reader can find its proof in [To3, Lemma 6.12].

Lemma 5.2. If $L$ and $c_{T}$ are chosen big enough, then

$$
\left|\nu\left(H_{\mathcal{D}} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}}\right)\right| \leq \frac{1}{2}|\nu(F)| \quad \text { and } \quad \mu\left(H_{\mathcal{D}} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}}\right) \leq \delta_{0} \mu(F)
$$

with $\delta_{0}<1$ constant.
5.3. Verifying the hypotheses of a $T b$-theorem. The goal of this subsection is to prove the lemma below, analogous to [To3, Lemma 6.8 (Main Lemma)]. We remark that in order to apply the $T b$-theorem found in [NTVol] we will still need to check an additional weak boundedness property for a particular suppressed kernel, due to the lack of anti-symmetry of our kernel $P$. Following the proof of the aforementioned reference or that of [To3, Theorem 5.1], one notices that such condition needs not to be verified, since the Cauchy kernel satisfies being anti-symmetric.

Lemma 5.3. Let $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a compact set verifying $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{1}}, \mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{2}}$ and $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{3}}$. Let $\mathcal{F}:=\cup_{i=1}^{N} \mathcal{Q}_{i}$ be the covering provided by Theorem 4.1, and $F:=\cup_{i=1}^{N} Q_{i}=\cup_{i=1}^{N} \frac{1}{2} \mathcal{Q}_{i}$, that still satisfies $E \subset F$. Let $\mu$ and $\nu$ be the measures defined in (5.1) and (5.2). Then, there exists a subset $H \subset F$, such that

1. $\nu=b \mu$ for some $b$ with $\|b\|_{\infty} \leq c_{1}$.
2. $|\nu(F)|=\widetilde{\gamma}(E) / 2$.
3. $c_{3}^{-1} \widetilde{\gamma}(E) \leq \mu(F) \leq c_{3} \widetilde{\gamma}(E)$.
4. For any cube $Q \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1},|\nu(Q)| \leq c_{4} \ell(Q)^{n}$.
5. If $\mathcal{P}_{*}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{*}^{*}$ denote the maximal convolution operators associated to $P$ and $P^{*}$ respectively, we have

$$
\int_{F \backslash H} \mathcal{P}_{*} \nu(\bar{x}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{x}) \leq c_{5} \mu(F), \quad \int_{F \backslash H} \mathcal{P}_{*}^{*} \nu(\bar{x}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{x}) \leq c_{5} \mu(F)
$$

6. If $\mu\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right)>L r^{n}$ (for some big constant $L$ ), then $B_{r}(\bar{x}) \subset H$. In particular, for any $\bar{x} \in F \backslash H$ and $r>0$, one has $\mu\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right) \leq L r^{n}$.
7. $H$ is of the form $\bigcup_{k \in I_{H}} B_{r_{k}}\left(\bar{x}_{k}\right)$, for some countable set of indices $I_{H}$. Moreover $\sum_{k \in I_{H}} r_{k}^{n} \leq \frac{5^{n}}{L} \mu(F)$.

The constants $c_{1}, c_{3}, c_{4}$ and $c_{5}$ are fixed, while $L$ can be chosen arbitrarily large.
Let us check that many of the hypothesis in Lemma 5.3 are verified for our particular choice of $\mu$ and $\nu$. Properties 1, 2 and 4 are proved in Lemma 5.1, and 3 follows from the third property of the same lemma, and by assumption $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{3}}$ combined with $r_{i}^{n} \approx \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)$. Moreover, taking $H \subset F$ to be as in (5.6), properties 6 and 7 are also guaranteed by definition. So it remains to check hypothesis 5 . To do so, let us begin by presenting a series of auxiliary results.

Lemma 5.4. Let $T$ be a distribution supported on a compact set $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ with $\|P *$ $T \|_{\infty} \leq 1$ or $\left\|P^{*} * T\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. Let $Q \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a cube and $\varphi \in \mathcal{C}_{c, \mathcal{X}}^{1}(2 Q)$ such that $\|\varphi\|_{\infty} \leq D \ell(Q)$ and $\|\nabla \varphi\|_{\infty} \leq A D$. Then

$$
|\langle T, \varphi\rangle| \lesssim D \ell(Q)^{n+1}
$$

Proof. Recall Remark 2.1 to notice that the proof is simply an application of [MPr, Corollary 3.3] to $\psi:=[2 A D \ell(Q)]^{-1} \varphi \in \mathcal{C}_{c, \mathcal{N}}^{1}(2 Q)$ that is such that $\|\nabla \psi\|_{\infty} \leq \ell(2 Q)^{-1}$. Observe that [MPr, Corollary 3.3] is also valid for $P^{*}$, which can be proved analogously using that $P^{*}$ is fundamental solution of the conjugate operator $\overline{\Theta}^{1 / 2}$.

Lemma 5.5. Let $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be compact set and $Q \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ a cube. If $T$ is a distribution supported on $E \subset Q$, then the following holds:

1. If $\left\|P * T\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ or $\left\|P^{*} * T\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ and $\varphi \in \mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{N}}^{1}(2 Q)$ satisfies $\|\varphi\|_{L^{\infty}(2 Q)} \leq D \ell(Q)$ and $\|\nabla \varphi\|_{L^{\infty}(2 Q)} \leq D$, then

$$
|\langle T, \varphi\rangle| \lesssim D \ell(Q)^{n+1}
$$

2. If $\|P * T\|_{\infty} \leq 1,\left\|P^{*} * T\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ and $\varphi$ is as above, then

$$
|\langle T, \varphi\rangle| \lesssim D \ell(Q) \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}(E)
$$

Proof. We prove 1 under the assumption $\|P * T\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ (the proof is analogous for $P^{*}$ ). Consider a test function $\psi \in \mathcal{C}_{c}^{\infty}(2 Q)$ with $\|\psi\|_{\infty} \leq 1,\|\nabla \psi\|_{\infty} \leq \ell(2 Q)^{-1}$ and $\left.\psi\right|_{Q} \equiv 1$. Notice that $\eta:=\varphi \psi$ belongs to $\mathcal{C}_{c, \mathcal{N}}^{1}(2 Q)$ and $\|\eta\|_{\infty} \leq D \ell(Q)$ and $\|\nabla \eta\|_{\infty} \leq 2 D$. Then, by Lemma 5.4 and the fact that $\operatorname{supp}(T) \subset E \subset Q$,

$$
|\langle T, \varphi\rangle|=|\langle T, \eta\rangle| \lesssim D \ell(Q)^{n+1}
$$

To prove 2, assume that $\|P * T\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ and $\left\|P^{*} * T\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. Consider $\psi$ as before and define the auxiliary function

$$
\eta:=[4 D \ell(Q)]^{-1} \varphi \psi \in \mathcal{C}_{c, \mathcal{N}}^{1}(2 Q)
$$

that is such that $\|\nabla \eta\|_{\infty} \leq \ell(2 Q)^{-1}$. By Remark 2.1, we shall apply [MPr, Theorem 3.1] to deduce $\|P * \eta T\|_{\infty} \lesssim 1$ and $\left\|P^{*} * \eta T\right\|_{\infty} \lesssim 1$. Hence $|\langle\eta T, 1\rangle| \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}(E)$, that by definition means

$$
|\langle T, \varphi\rangle| \lesssim D \ell(Q) \cdot \widetilde{\gamma}(E)
$$

Let us now consider a distribution $T$ supported on $E \subset Q=Q\left(c_{Q}, \ell(Q)\right)$ with $\|P * T\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ and $\left\|P^{*} * T\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. Fix any $\bar{z} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 3 Q$ and set

$$
\varphi_{\bar{z}}(\cdot):=P(\bar{z}-\cdot)-P\left(\bar{z}-c_{Q}\right), \quad \varphi_{\bar{z}}^{*}(\cdot):=P^{*}(\bar{z}-\cdot)-P^{*}\left(\bar{z}-c_{Q}\right)
$$

Write $\bar{z}=(z, \tau)$ and let $\bar{y}=(y, s)$ be a generic point in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. We define the null set $\mathcal{N}=\mathcal{N}(\bar{z})$ to be the horizontal hyperplane

$$
\mathcal{N}:=\left\{\bar{y} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}: s=\tau\right\}
$$

This way $\varphi_{\bar{z}}, \varphi_{\bar{z}}^{*} \in \mathcal{C}_{\mathcal{N}}^{\infty}(2 Q)$. Moreover, for any $\bar{y} \in 2 Q$, by [MPr, Lemma 2.1],

$$
\left|\varphi_{\bar{z}}(\bar{y})\right|=\left|P(\bar{z}-\bar{y})-P\left(\bar{z}-c_{Q}\right)\right| \lesssim \frac{\left|\bar{y}-c_{Q}\right|}{\left|\bar{z}-c_{Q}\right|^{n+1}} \lesssim \frac{\ell(Q)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{z}, E)^{n+1}}
$$

and for any $\bar{y} \in 2 Q \backslash \mathcal{N}$,

$$
\left|\nabla \varphi_{\bar{z}}(\bar{y})\right|=|\nabla P(\bar{z}-\bar{y})| \lesssim \frac{1}{|\bar{z}-\bar{y}|^{n+1}} \leq \frac{3^{n+1}}{\left|\bar{z}-c_{Q}\right|} \lesssim \frac{1}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{z}, E)^{n+1}}
$$

and the same bounds clearly also hold for $\varphi_{\bar{\varepsilon}}^{*}$. Therefore we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\varphi_{\bar{\varepsilon}}\right\|_{L^{\infty}(2 Q)} & \lesssim \frac{\ell(Q)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{\varepsilon}, E)^{n+1}}, & \left\|\varphi_{\bar{\varepsilon}}^{*}\right\|_{L^{\infty}(2 Q)} \lesssim \frac{\ell(Q)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{\varepsilon}, E)^{n+1}} \\
\left\|\nabla \varphi_{\bar{\varepsilon}}\right\|_{L^{\infty}(2 Q)} & \lesssim \frac{\ell(Q)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{\varepsilon}, E)^{n+1}}, & \left\|\nabla \varphi_{\bar{\varepsilon}}^{*}\right\|_{L^{\infty}(2 Q)} \lesssim \frac{1}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{\varepsilon}, E)^{n+1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the identities

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|P * T(\bar{\varepsilon})-\langle T, 1\rangle P\left(\bar{\varepsilon}-c_{Q}\right)\right| & =\left|\left\langle T, \varphi_{\bar{\varepsilon}}\right\rangle\right| \\
\left|P^{*} * T(\bar{\varepsilon})-\langle T, 1\rangle P^{*}\left(\bar{\varepsilon}-c_{Q}\right)\right| & =\left|\left\langle T, \varphi_{\bar{\varepsilon}}^{*}\right\rangle\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

a direct application of the second statement in Lemma 5.5 yields
Corollary 5.6. Let $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a compact set contained in the cube $Q=Q\left(c_{Q}, \ell(Q)\right)$, and $T$ a distribution admissible for $\widetilde{\gamma}(E)$. Then, for any $\bar{\varepsilon} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 3 Q$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|P * T(\bar{\varepsilon})-\langle T, 1\rangle P\left(\bar{\varepsilon}-c_{Q}\right)\right| & \lesssim \frac{\ell(Q)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{\varepsilon}, E)^{n+1}} \widetilde{\gamma}(E) \\
\left|P^{*} * T(\bar{\varepsilon})-\langle T, 1\rangle P^{*}\left(\bar{\varepsilon}-c_{Q}\right)\right| & \lesssim \frac{\ell(Q)}{\operatorname{dist}(\bar{\varepsilon}, E)^{n+1}} \widetilde{\gamma}(E)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lemma 5.7. Let

$$
\widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}:=\left.\frac{\left\langle T_{0}, \varphi_{i}\right\rangle}{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{i}\right)} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}\right|_{B_{i}}, \quad i=1, \ldots, N
$$

For each $i=1, \ldots, N$, we have

1. $\left\|P * \varphi_{i} T_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \lesssim 1$ and $\left\|P * \widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}\right\|_{\infty} \lesssim 1$.
2. For any $\bar{\varepsilon} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 3 Q_{i}$,

$$
\left|P * \varphi_{i} T_{0}(\bar{\varepsilon})-P * \widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}(\bar{\varepsilon})\right| \lesssim \frac{\ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right)}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{\varepsilon}, 2 Q_{i}\right)^{n+1}} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)
$$

The same results hold changing $P$ by $P^{*}$.
Proof. The first estimate in 1 is just a consequence of the localization result [MPr, Theorem 3.1]. Regarding the second, fix $\bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and compute:

$$
\left|P * \widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}\right|(\bar{x}) \leq \frac{\left|\left\langle T_{0}, \varphi_{i}\right\rangle\right|}{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{i}\right)} \int_{B_{i}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}} \lesssim \frac{1}{r_{i}} \int_{B_{i}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}}
$$

where we have used that $\left|\left\langle T_{0}, \varphi_{i}\right\rangle\right| \lesssim r_{i}^{n}$, that has already been argued in (5.3). We deal with remaining integral as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{B_{i}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}} & =\int_{B_{i} \cap\left\{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}| \geq r_{i}\right\}} \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}}+\int_{B_{i} \cap\left\{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|<r_{i}\right\}} \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}} \\
& \leq \frac{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{i}\right)}{r_{i}^{n}}+\int_{B_{4 r_{i}}(\bar{x})} \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}} \lesssim r_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let us prove 2: fix $\bar{z} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 3 Q_{i}$ and notice

$$
\left|P * \varphi_{i} T_{0}(\bar{z})-P * \widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}(\bar{z})\right|=\left|P * \varphi_{i} T_{0}(\bar{z})-\frac{\left\langle\varphi_{i} T_{0}, 1\right\rangle}{r_{i}^{n}} P * \mu_{i}(\bar{z})\right|
$$

where

$$
\frac{1}{r_{i}^{n}} P * \mu_{i}(\bar{z})=\int_{B_{i}}\left(P(\bar{z}-\bar{y})-P\left(\bar{z}-c_{B_{i}}\right)\right) \frac{\mathrm{d} \mu_{i}(\bar{y})}{r_{i}^{n}}+P\left(\bar{z}-c_{B_{i}}\right)
$$

Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|P * \varphi_{i} T_{0}(\bar{z})-P * \overline{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}(\bar{z})\right| \\
& \leq\left|P * \varphi_{i} T_{0}(\bar{z})-\left\langle\varphi_{i} T_{0}, 1\right\rangle P\left(\bar{z}-c_{B_{i}}\right)\right| \\
& +\frac{\left|\left\langle\varphi_{i} T_{0}, 1\right\rangle\right|}{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{i}\right)} \int_{B_{i}}\left|P(\bar{z}-\bar{y})-P\left(\bar{z}-c_{B_{i}}\right)\right| \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})
\end{aligned}
$$

Apply Corollary 5.6 to $T:=\varphi_{i} T_{0}$, admissible for $\tilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)$ to deduce

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|P * \varphi_{i} T_{0}(\bar{z})-\left\langle\varphi_{i} T_{0}, 1\right\rangle P\left(\bar{z}-c_{B_{i}}\right)\right| & \lesssim \frac{\ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right)}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)^{n+1}} \tilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \\
& \leq \frac{\ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right)}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)^{n+1}} \tilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By [MPr, Lemma 2.1] and estimates in the proof of Lemma 5.1 we also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\left|\left\langle\varphi_{i} T_{0}, 1\right\rangle\right|}{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{i}\right)} \int_{B_{i}}\left|P(\bar{z}-\bar{y})-\right. & P\left(\bar{z}-c_{B_{i}}\right) \mid \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y}) \\
& \lesssim \frac{1}{r_{i}} \frac{1}{\left|\bar{z}-c_{B_{i}}\right|^{n+1}} \int_{B_{i}}\left|\bar{y}-c_{B_{i}}\right| \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y}) \\
& \lesssim \frac{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{i}\right)}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)^{n+1}} \approx \frac{r_{i}}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)^{n+1}} \tilde{\gamma}\left(2 \mathcal{Q}_{i} \cap E\right) \\
& \leq \frac{\ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right)}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)^{n+1}} \tilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using (5.11) and (5.12) in (5.10) we finish the proof of 2.
Our next goal will be to obtain a regularized version of statement 2 in Lemma 5.7. Consider $\psi$ a smooth radial function $\psi$ supported on $B_{1}(0)$ with $0 \leq \psi \leq 1, \int \psi=1$ and $\|\nabla \psi\|_{\infty} \leq 1$, and set

$$
\Psi_{\varepsilon}(\bar{x}):=\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n+1}} \psi\left(\frac{\bar{x}}{\varepsilon}\right), \quad \varepsilon>0
$$

Notice that $\int \Psi_{\varepsilon}=1$ for every $\varepsilon>0$. Define the regularized kernels

$$
R_{\varepsilon}:=\Psi_{\varepsilon} * P, \quad R_{\varepsilon}^{*}:=\Psi_{\varepsilon} * P^{*}
$$

as well as $\mathcal{R}_{\mu, \varepsilon}$ and $\mathcal{R}_{\mu, \varepsilon}^{*}$, its associated convolution operators with respect to the finite Borel measure $\mu$.

Remark 5.2. Observe that, in particular, for a point $\bar{x}_{0}=\left(x_{0}, t_{0}\right)$ with $\left|\bar{x}_{0}\right|>\varepsilon$ and $t_{0} \neq 0$ we have

$$
R_{\varepsilon}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)=P\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad R_{\varepsilon}^{*}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)=P^{*}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)
$$

This follows as in [Vo, Equation 3.32], using the harmonicity of $P$ and $P^{*}$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash\{t=0\}$ and the mean value property in that domain. Notice that we need the spherical symmetry of $\Psi_{\varepsilon}$ and $\int \Psi_{\varepsilon}=1$ to ensure this.

On the other hand, for any $\bar{x}_{0}$ such that $\left|\bar{x}_{0}\right|<\varepsilon$ we have

$$
\left|R_{\varepsilon}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right| \lesssim \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n}} \quad \text { and } \quad\left|R_{\varepsilon}^{*}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right| \lesssim \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n}}
$$

Indeed, using the definition of $\Psi$ and the fact that $0 \leq \psi \leq 1$, we get

$$
\left|R_{\varepsilon}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right| \leq \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n+1}} \int_{B_{\varepsilon}(0)} \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x})}{\left|\bar{x}_{0}-\bar{x}\right|^{n}} \leq \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n+1}} \int_{2 B_{\varepsilon}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)} \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x})}{\left|\bar{x}_{0}-\bar{x}\right|^{n}} \lesssim \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n}}
$$

and analogously for $R_{\varepsilon}^{*}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$.
Lemma 5.8. For any $\bar{z} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 4 Q_{i}$, any $\varepsilon>0$ and each $i=1, \ldots, N$,

$$
\left|R_{\varepsilon} * \varphi_{i} T_{0}(\bar{z})-R_{\varepsilon} * \overline{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}(\bar{z})\right| \lesssim \frac{\ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right)}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)^{n+1}} \bar{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)
$$

The same result holds changing $R_{\varepsilon}$ by $R_{\varepsilon}^{*}$.
Proof. We will proof the result only for $R_{\varepsilon}$, since the arguments for $R_{\varepsilon}^{*}$ are analogous. Fix $\bar{z} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 4 Q_{i}$ and $\varepsilon<\frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)$. This way, since for any $\bar{y} \in B_{\varepsilon}(\bar{z})$ we have $\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{y}, 2 Q_{i}\right) \approx \operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)$, by Lemma 5.7 and the fact that $\int_{B_{\varepsilon}(\bar{z})} \Psi_{\varepsilon}(\bar{z}-\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \bar{y}=1$ we deduce

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|R_{\varepsilon} * \varphi_{i} T_{0}(\bar{z})-R_{\varepsilon} * \overline{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}(\bar{z})\right| & \leq \int_{B_{\varepsilon}(\bar{z})} \Psi_{\varepsilon}(\bar{z}-\bar{y})\left|P * \varphi_{i} T_{0}(\bar{y})-P * \overline{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}(\bar{y})\right| \mathrm{d} \bar{y} \\
& \lesssim \frac{\ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right)}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)^{n+1}} \bar{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

the desired inequality. Hence, we are only left to study the case $\varepsilon \geq \frac{1}{2} \operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)$. Observe that in this setting, since $\bar{z} \notin 4 Q_{i}$ we have $\varepsilon \gtrsim \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)$. Write

$$
\alpha_{i}:=\varphi_{i} T_{0}-\overline{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}
$$

so that

$$
\left|R_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}(\bar{z})\right| \leq \int_{\operatorname{supp}\left(\Psi_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}\right)} P(\bar{z}-\bar{y})\left|\Psi_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}(\bar{y})\right| \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})
$$

Observe that $\operatorname{supp}\left(\overline{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}\right) \subset B_{i}, \operatorname{supp}\left(\varphi_{i} T_{0}\right) \subset 2 Q_{i} \cap E$ and $\operatorname{supp}\left(\Psi_{\varepsilon}\right) \subset B_{\varepsilon}(0)$. Then, the support of $\Psi_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}$ is contained in $\mathcal{U}_{\varepsilon}\left(2 Q_{i}\right)$, an open $\varepsilon$-neighborhood of $2 Q_{i}$. This implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|R_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}(\bar{z})\right| & \leq\left\|\Psi_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}\right\|_{\infty} \int_{\mathcal{U}_{\varepsilon}\left(2 Q_{i}\right)} \frac{\mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{z}-\bar{y}|^{n}} \lesssim\left(\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)+\varepsilon\right) \cdot\left\|\Psi_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \lesssim \varepsilon \cdot\left\|\Psi_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}\right\|_{\infty}
\end{aligned}
$$

by integrating over decreasing annuli centered at $\bar{z}$, and using that $\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right) \leq 2 \varepsilon$ and $\varepsilon \gtrsim \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)$. On the other hand, if $\eta_{i} \in \mathcal{C}_{\varepsilon}^{\infty}\left(3 Q_{i}\right)$ with $0 \leq \eta_{i} \leq 1, \eta_{i} \equiv 1$ on $2 Q_{i}$ (where the support of $\alpha_{i}$ is contained) and $\left\|\nabla \eta_{i}\right\|_{\infty} \leq \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)^{-1}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Psi_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}(\bar{w}) & =\left\langle\Psi_{\varepsilon}(\bar{w}-\cdot), \alpha_{i}\right\rangle=\left\langle\Psi_{\varepsilon}(\bar{w}-\cdot)-\Psi_{\varepsilon}\left(\bar{w}-c_{Q_{i}}\right), \alpha_{i}\right\rangle \\
& =\left\langle\left(\Psi_{\varepsilon}(\bar{w}-\cdot)-\Psi_{\varepsilon}\left(\bar{w}-c_{Q_{i}}\right)\right) \eta_{i}, \alpha_{i}\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used $\left\langle\varphi_{i} T_{0}, 1\right\rangle=\left\langle\overline{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}, 1\right\rangle$.
We claim that for each $\bar{w} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$, the function

$$
\varphi(\bar{\xi}):=\left(\Psi_{\varepsilon}(\bar{w}-\xi)-\Psi_{\varepsilon}\left(\bar{w}-c_{Q_{i}}\right)\right) \eta_{i}(\xi)
$$

satisfies $\|\varphi\|_{\infty} \lesssim \varepsilon^{-\langle n+2\rangle} \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)$ and $\|\nabla \varphi\|_{\infty} \lesssim \varepsilon^{-\langle n+2\rangle}$. Then, using that statement 1 in Lemma 5.7 implies that $\varphi T_{0}$ is admissible for $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)$ and that $\overline{\varphi T_{0}}$ is admissible for $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(B_{i}\right)$, we have, by Lemma 5.5,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\Psi_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}\right|=\left|\left\langle\varphi, \alpha_{i}\right\rangle\right| & \lesssim \frac{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)}{\varepsilon^{n+2}}\left\{\widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)+\widetilde{\gamma}\left(B_{i}\right)\right\} \\
& \lesssim \frac{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)}{\varepsilon^{n+2}}\left\{\widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)+r_{i}^{n}\right\} \approx \frac{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)}{\varepsilon^{n+2}} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\left|R_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}(\bar{z})\right| \lesssim \varepsilon \cdot\left\|\Psi_{\varepsilon} * \alpha_{i}\right\|_{\infty} \lesssim \frac{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)}{\varepsilon^{n+1}} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \lesssim \frac{\ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right)}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right)^{n+1}} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right)
$$

where we have used $\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{z}, 2 Q_{i}\right) \leq 2 \varepsilon$, and we deduce the desired estimate. Hence, we are left to prove the claim. Let us fix $\bar{w} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and compute: on the one hand

$$
\|\varphi\|_{\infty}=\|\varphi\|_{L^{\infty}\left(3 Q_{i}\right)} \leq \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n+2}} \sup _{\bar{\xi} \in 3 Q_{i}}\left|\bar{\xi}-c_{Q_{i}}\right| \cdot\|\nabla \psi\|_{\infty} \lesssim \frac{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)}{\varepsilon^{n+2}}
$$

while on the other hand

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\nabla \varphi\|_{\infty} & =\|\nabla \varphi\|_{L^{\infty}\left(3 Q_{i}\right)} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{\ell\left(Q_{i}\right)} \sup _{\bar{\xi} \in 3 Q_{i}}\left|\Psi_{\varepsilon}(\bar{w}-\bar{\xi})-\Psi_{\varepsilon}\left(\bar{w}-c_{Q_{i}}\right)\right|+\frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n+2}}\|\nabla \psi\|_{\infty} \lesssim \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n+2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, we are done.
Let us finally prove property 5 in Lemma 5.3:
Lemma 5.9. The following estimates hold:

$$
\int_{F \backslash H} \mathcal{P}_{*} \nu(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \lesssim \mu(F), \quad \int_{F \backslash H} \mathcal{P}_{*}^{*} \nu(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \lesssim \mu(F)
$$

Proof. We only prove the first estimate, since the proof of the second is analogous. Begin by noticing that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{F \backslash H} \mathcal{P}_{*} \nu(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y})=\int_{F \backslash H} \sup _{\varepsilon>0}\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \\
& \quad \leq \int_{F \backslash H} \sup _{\varepsilon>0}\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon} \nu(\bar{y})-\mathcal{R}_{\varepsilon} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y})+\int_{F \backslash H} \sup _{\varepsilon>0}\left|\mathcal{R}_{\varepsilon} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y})=: I_{1}+I_{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

For $I_{1}$, observe that for each $\varepsilon>0$ and $\bar{y}=(y, s) \in F \backslash H$, since $\nu \ll \mu \ll \mathcal{L}^{n+1}$, we have

$$
\nu\left(\left\{(z, \tau) \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}: \tau=s\right\}\right)=0
$$

so applying Remark 5.2 we deduce

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon} \nu(\bar{y})-\mathcal{R}_{\varepsilon} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \\
& \quad=\left|\int_{|\bar{y}-\bar{z}| \leq \varepsilon} R_{\varepsilon}(\bar{y}-\bar{z}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{z})+\int_{|\bar{y}-\bar{z}|>\varepsilon} R_{\varepsilon}(\bar{y}-\bar{z}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{z})-\int_{|\bar{y}-\bar{z}|>\varepsilon} P(\bar{y}-\bar{z}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{z})\right| \\
& \quad=\left|\int_{|\bar{y}-\bar{z}| \leq \varepsilon} R_{\varepsilon}(\bar{y}-\bar{z}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{z})\right| \leq \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n}}|\nu|\left(B_{\varepsilon}(\bar{y})\right) \lesssim \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{n}} \mu\left(B_{\varepsilon}(\bar{y})\right) \leq M \mu(\bar{y})
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, using that $\bar{y} \in F \backslash H$ we get $\left|I_{1}\right| \lesssim \mu(F)$. So we are left to estimate $I_{2}$. We introduce the notation

$$
R_{*} * \nu(\bar{y}):=\sup _{\varepsilon>0}\left|R_{\varepsilon} * \nu(\bar{y})\right|
$$

so that

$$
I_{2}:=\int_{F \backslash H} R_{*} * \nu(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \leq \int_{F \backslash H} R_{*} * T_{0}(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y})+\int_{F \backslash H} R_{*} *\left(\nu-T_{0}\right)(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y})
$$

Since $\left\|P * T_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$ by construction, we also have $\left\|R_{\varepsilon} * T_{0}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$, uniformly on $\varepsilon>0$. For the second integral in $I_{2}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{F \backslash H} R_{*} *\left(\nu-T_{0}\right)(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \leq \sum_{i=1}^{N} \int_{F \backslash H} R_{*} *\left(\widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}-\varphi_{i} T_{0}\right)(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \\
& \quad=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\int_{4 Q_{i}} R_{*} *\left(\widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}-\varphi_{i} T_{0}\right)(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y})+\int_{F \backslash\left(4 Q_{i} ; ; H\right)} R_{*} *\left(\widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}-\varphi_{i} T_{0}\right)(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y})\right) \\
& \quad=: \sum_{i=1}^{N} I_{i, 1}+I_{i, 2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the first inequality we have used that $\sum_{i} \varphi_{i} \equiv 1$ on $F$ and $\nu=\sum_{i} \widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}$. For each $i=1, \ldots, N$ we set $\alpha_{i}:=\widetilde{\varphi_{i} T_{0}}-\varphi_{i} T_{0}$ and apply the first statement in Lemma 5.7 to deduce $\left\|P * \alpha_{i}\right\|_{\infty} \lesssim 1$. Hence, $I_{i, 1} \lesssim \mu\left(4 Q_{i}\right)$. To estimate $I_{i, 2}$ we will use Lemma 5.8. Let $N$ be the smallest integer such that

$$
A_{N}:=\left(4^{N+1} Q_{i} \backslash 4^{N} Q_{i}\right) \backslash H \neq \varnothing
$$

Then,

$$
I_{i, 2} \lesssim \ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right) \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \sum_{k=N}^{\infty} \int_{A_{N}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mu(\bar{y})}{\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{y}, 2 Q_{i}\right)^{n+1}} \lesssim \ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right) \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \sum_{k=N}^{\infty} \frac{\mu\left(4^{k+1} Q_{i}\right)}{\left(4^{k} \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)\right)^{n+1}}
$$

Observe that for any $\bar{x} \in A_{N}$, we have for each $k \geq N$

$$
\mu\left(4^{k+1} Q_{i}\right) \leq \mu\left(B_{2 \cdot \operatorname{diam}\left(4^{k+1} Q_{i}\right)}(\bar{x})\right) \lesssim\left(4^{k} \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)\right)^{n}
$$

where we have used that $\bar{x} \notin H$. Therefore,

$$
I_{i, 2} \lesssim \ell\left(2 Q_{i}\right) \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \sum_{k=N}^{\infty} \frac{1}{4^{k} \ell\left(Q_{i}\right)} \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 Q_{i} \cap E\right) \approx r_{i}^{n}=\mu\left(B_{i}\right)
$$

Since the cubes $10 Q_{1}, \ldots, 10 Q_{N}$ have bounded overlap we conclude that

$$
\int_{F \backslash H} R_{*} *\left(\nu-T_{0}\right)(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \lesssim \sum_{i=1}^{N} \mu\left(4 Q_{i}\right) \lesssim \mu(F)
$$

The proof of 5 concludes that of Lemma 5.3. In order to apply the $T b$-theorem of [NTVo1] or [To3, Theorem 5.1] we still need to check an additional weak boundedness property for our $n$-dimensional C-Z kernel, which fails being anti-symmetric.

5.4. The exceptional sets $\mathcal{S}$ and $W_{\mathcal{D}}$. The additional eighth property. Assume that $F \subset B_{2^{N-3}}(0)$ for some integer $N$ large enough. Observe that assumption $\mathbf{A}_{2}$ together with properties 1 and 4 in Theorem 4.1 imply that we can take $N=4$, for example. We write

$$
\Omega:=\left[-2^{N-1}, 2^{N-1}\right)^{n+1}
$$

and consider the random cube $Q^{0}(\bar{w}):=\bar{w}+\left[-2^{N}, 2^{N}\right)^{n+1}$, with $\bar{w} \in \Omega$. Observe that $F \subset Q^{0}(\bar{w})$ for any $\bar{w} \in \Omega$. Let $\mathbb{P}$ be the uniform probability measure on $\Omega$, that is, the normalized Lebesgue measure on the cube $\Omega$.

When carefully reviewing the proofs of the the non-homogeneous $T b$-theorems of [To3, §5] and [Vo], one encounters expressions that, in our context, would be of the form

$$
\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}\left(\chi_{\Delta} b\right),\left(\chi_{\Delta} b\right)\right\rangle:=\int_{\Delta} \int_{\Delta} P_{\Lambda}(\bar{x}, \bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{x})
$$

where $\Lambda$ is a certain 1-Lipschitz function associated to the suppressed kernel $P_{\Lambda}, \Delta=$ $P \cap S$ is a parallelepiped obtained as the intersection of two cubes $P \in \mathcal{D}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)=: \mathcal{D}_{1}$, $S \in \mathcal{D}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)=: \mathcal{D}_{2}$, with $\bar{w}_{1}, \bar{w}_{2} \in \Omega$, and $\mathcal{D}_{1}$ and $\mathcal{D}_{2}$ are two dyadic lattices which are reciprocally good to one another. Moreover, such cubes $P, S$ satisfy $P \subset F \backslash\left(H_{\mathcal{D}_{1}} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}\right)$ and $S \subset F \backslash\left(H_{\mathcal{D}_{2}} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}\right)$. The latter inclusions imply that $P$ is a transit cube with respect to $\mathcal{D}_{1}$ and we write $P \in \mathcal{D}_{1}^{\text {tr }}$, and analogously for $S$ with respect to $\mathcal{D}_{2}$ (we will specify the precise meaning of the terms good and transit in Remark 5.3). $P, S$ and all their dyadic children have $M$-thin boundaries (with respect to $\mu$ ), for some $M>0$ dimensional constant. Recall that we say that a set $X \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ has $M$-thin boundary if

$$
\mu\left(\left\{\bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}: \operatorname{dist}(\bar{x}, \partial X) \leq \tau\right\}\right) \leq M \tau^{n}, \quad \text { for all } \tau>0
$$

As one may expect, expressions of the form $\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}\left(\chi_{\Delta} b\right),\left(\chi_{\Delta} b\right)\right\rangle$ are null if the kernel associated to the operator $\mathcal{P}$ is anti-symmetric, as it occurs in [To3] with the Cauchy kernel, or in [Vo] with the vector Riesz kernel. If this is not the case, following the proofs of general non-homogeneous $T b$-theorems and, more precisely, the arguments of [NTVo2, $\S 10.2]$ or [HyMar, §9], the latter expressions can be dealt with if we have $\left\|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \varepsilon} \nu\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\mu)} \lesssim$ $1,\left\|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \varepsilon}^{*} \nu\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\mu)} \lesssim 1$ uniformly on $\varepsilon>0$, as well as the following weak boundedness property

$$
\left|\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}\left(\chi_{Q} b\right),\left(\chi_{Q} b\right)\right\rangle\right| \lesssim \mu(\lambda Q), \quad \lambda>1
$$

that suffices to hold for cubes $Q$ with $M$-thin boundary and contained in parallelepipeds $\Delta$ of the form $P \cap S$, where $P$ and $S$ are as above. Such kind of restricted weak boundedness property for cubes with thin boundary is already checked in the proofs of [MPrTo, Theorem 5.5] and [MPr, Theorem 4.3].

Our goal in this subsection will be to verify the above conditions by choosing a proper 1-Lipschitz function $\Lambda$ which will depend on an additional exceptional set $\mathcal{S}$. If such additional properties hold, the proofs of the $T b$-theorems found in [To3, Ch.5] and [Vo] can be adapted to our non anti-symmetric setting. To define the exceptional set $\mathcal{S}$, we will follow an analogous construction to that of [To3, §5.2]. We begin by writing

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathcal{S}_{1}^{\prime}:=\left\{\bar{x} \in F: \mathcal{P}_{*} \nu(\bar{x})>\alpha\right\} \\
& \mathcal{S}_{2}^{\prime}:=\left\{\bar{x} \in F: \mathcal{P}_{\nu, *}^{*} 1(\bar{x})>\alpha\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

for a large constant $\alpha>0$ to be chosen below. For the moment, let us say that $\alpha \gg c_{1} L$. We also write,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { for } \bar{x} \in \mathcal{S}_{1}^{\prime}: \quad e_{1}(\bar{x}):=\sup \left\{\varepsilon>0:\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon} \nu(\bar{x})\right|>\alpha\right\} \\
& \text { for } \bar{x} \in \mathcal{S}_{2}^{\prime}: \quad e_{2}(\bar{x}):=\sup \left\{\varepsilon>0:\left|\mathcal{P}_{\nu, \varepsilon}^{*} 1(\bar{x})\right|>\alpha\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\bar{x} \in F \backslash\left(\mathcal{S}_{1}^{\prime} \cup \mathcal{S}_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ we convey $e_{1}(\bar{x})=e_{2}(\bar{x}):=0$. We define also

$$
\mathcal{S}_{1}:=\bigcup_{\bar{x} \in \mathcal{S}_{1}^{\prime}} B_{e_{1}(\bar{x})}(\bar{x}) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{S}_{2}:=\bigcup_{\bar{x} \in \mathcal{S}_{2}^{\prime}} B_{e_{2}(\bar{x})}(\bar{x})
$$

as well as the exceptional set

$$
\mathcal{S}:=\mathcal{S}_{1} \cup \mathcal{S}_{2}
$$

Let us first show that for any $\bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}, \mu\left(\mathcal{S} \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})}\right)$ is small if $\alpha$ is taken big enough. The proof of the following lemma is analogous to that of [To3, Lemma 5.2].

Lemma 5.10. Let $\bar{x}_{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and $\mathcal{D}:=\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$. Then, for $\alpha>0$ big enough,

$$
\mu\left(\mathcal{S} \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}}\right) \leq \frac{4 c_{5}}{\alpha} \mu(F)
$$

Proof. Let $\bar{y} \in \mathcal{S} \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}}$ and assume, for example, $\bar{y} \in \mathcal{S}_{1}$.
