Then $\bar{y} \in B_{e_{1}(\bar{x})}(\bar{x})$ for some $\bar{x} \in \mathcal{S}_{1}^{\prime}$. Let $\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})$ be such that $\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})} \nu\right|>\alpha$ and $\bar{y} \in B_{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})}(\bar{x})$. Observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})} \nu(\bar{x})-\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \leq\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})}\left(\chi_{B_{2 c_{0}(\bar{x})}(\bar{y})} \nu\right) \bar{x}\right)\right|+\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})}\left(\chi_{B_{2 c_{0}(\bar{x})}(\bar{y})} \nu\right)(\bar{y})\right| \\
&+c_{1} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash B_{2 c_{0}(\bar{x})}(\bar{y})}|P(\bar{x}-\bar{z})-P(\bar{y}-\bar{z})| \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{z})
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\bar{y} \notin H_{\mathcal{D}}$, the first two terms are bounded above by

$$
c_{1} \frac{\mu\left(B_{2 c_{0}(\bar{x})}(\bar{y})\right)}{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})^{n}} \leq 2^{n} L c_{1}
$$

Regarding the third term, if $A$ is the C-Z constant of $P$ from property (c) of [MPT, Lemma 2.1], integration over annuli and using again that $\bar{y} \notin H_{\mathcal{D}}$ yield

$$
c_{1} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash B_{2 c_{0}(\bar{x})}(\bar{y})}|P(\bar{x}-\bar{z})-P(\bar{y}-\bar{z})| \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{z}) \lesssim 2^{n} A L c_{1}
$$

Therefore, naming $\kappa:=2^{n} L c_{1}(2+A)$, we have $\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})} \nu(\bar{x})-\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \leq \kappa$, and thus

$$
\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon_{0}(\bar{x})} \nu(\bar{y})\right|>\alpha-\kappa
$$

which implies, in particular, $\mathcal{P}_{*} \nu(\bar{y})>\alpha-\kappa$. If we have had $\bar{y} \in \mathcal{S}_{2}$ we would have obtained the same bound for $\mathcal{P}_{*}^{*} \nu(\bar{y})$, since $P$ and $P^{*}$ share the same C-Z constants. In any case, pick

$$
\alpha \geq 2 \kappa
$$

and observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mu\left(\mathcal{S} \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}}\right) & \leq \int_{\mathcal{S}_{1} \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}}} \mathrm{d} \mu+\int_{\mathcal{S}_{2} \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}}} \mathrm{d} \mu \\
& \leq \frac{2}{\alpha} \int_{F \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}}} \mathcal{P}_{*} \nu \mathrm{~d} \mu+\frac{2}{\alpha} \int_{F \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}}} \mathcal{P}_{*}^{*} \nu \mathrm{~d} \mu \leq \frac{4 c_{5}}{\alpha} \mu(F)
\end{aligned}
$$

One of the implications of the above lemma is the following: by setting $\delta_{1}:=\left(1+\delta_{0}\right) / 2$ (where $\delta_{0}$ is the parameter appearing in Lemma 5.2), we have $\delta_{0}<\delta_{1}<1$, and choosing $\alpha:=\max \left\{2 \kappa, 8 c_{5} /\left(1-\delta_{0}\right)\right\}$, we get

$$
\mu\left(H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})}\right)+\mu\left(\mathcal{S} \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})}\right) \leq \delta_{1} \mu(F), \quad \forall \bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}
$$

With this in mind, and defining the total exceptional set

$$
W_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})}:=H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})} \cup \mathcal{S}
$$

one obtains

$$
\mu\left(F \backslash W_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{x})}\right) \geq\left(1-\delta_{1}\right) \mu(F)
$$

which is a necessary inequality in order to carry out the final probabilistic argument in the proof of the $T b$-theorem (see [To3, §5.11.2]).

The exceptional set $\mathcal{S}$ exhibits additional important properties regarding suppressed kernels (see subsection 3.1), provided their associated 1-Lipschitz function $\Lambda$ satisfies certain conditions. In order to prove them, we present two preliminary results. Fix $\sigma$ any finite Borel measure in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and $\Lambda: \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \rightarrow[0, \infty)$ a 1-Lipschitz function. The following result will be useful in the sequel, and its proof is analogous to that of [Vo, Lemma 8.3].

Lemma 5.11. For any $\bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and any $\varepsilon \geq \Lambda(\bar{x})$,

$$
\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon} \sigma(\bar{x})-\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \varepsilon} \sigma(\bar{x})\right| \lesssim \sup _{r \geq \Lambda(\bar{x})} \frac{|\sigma|\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right)}{r^{n}}
$$

The same result holds changing $\mathcal{P}$ by $\mathcal{P}^{*}$.
In light of the previous result, the following lemma also follows and its proof is analogous to that of [To3, Lemma 5.5].

Lemma 5.12. Let $\bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and $r_{0}>0$ such that $\mu\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right) \leq L r^{n}$ for $r \geq r_{0}$, as well as $\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon} \nu(\bar{x})\right| \leq \alpha$ and $\left|\mathcal{P}_{\varepsilon}^{*} \nu(\bar{x})\right| \leq \alpha$ for $\varepsilon \geq r_{0}$. If $\Lambda(\bar{x}) \geq r_{0}$, then

$$
\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \varepsilon} \nu(\bar{x})\right| \lesssim \alpha+c_{1} L \quad \text { and } \quad\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \varepsilon}^{*} \nu(\bar{x})\right| \lesssim \alpha+c_{1} L
$$

uniformly on $\varepsilon>0$.
Bearing in mind the above result, we choose our 1-Lipschitz function $\Lambda: \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \rightarrow[0, \infty)$ to satisfy, for some $\bar{x}_{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$,

$$
\Lambda(\bar{x}) \geq \operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{x}, \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash\left(H_{\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)} \cup \mathcal{S}\right)\right)
$$

This choice is consistent with the Lipschitz functions $\Lambda$ that appear in the proofs of the $T b$-theorems presented in [To3, Ch.5] and [Vo], in the sense that they are constructed to ensure that the previous inequality is satisfied. This way, since $H_{\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)} \cup \mathcal{S}$ contains all non-Ahlfors balls and all the balls $B_{e_{1}(\bar{x})}(\bar{x}), B_{e_{2}(\bar{x})}(\bar{x})$ for $\bar{x} \in F$, we have

$$
\Lambda(\bar{x}) \geq \max \left\{\mathcal{R}(\bar{x}), e_{1}(\bar{x}), e_{2}(\bar{x})\right\}
$$

where $\mathcal{R}(\bar{x})$ is the Ahlfors radius defined in (5.5). So by the definition of $\mathcal{S}$ and choosing $r_{0}:=\max \left\{\mathcal{R}(\bar{x}), e_{1}(\bar{x}), e_{2}(\bar{x})\right\}$, Lemma 5.2 yields

Lemma 5.13. Let $\bar{x}_{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and $\Lambda: \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \rightarrow[0, \infty)$ a 1-Lipschitz function such that $\Lambda(\bar{x}) \geq \operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{x}, \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash\left(H_{\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)} \cup \mathcal{S}\right)\right)$ for all $\bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. Then,

$$
\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \nu} \nu(\bar{x}) \leq c_{\Lambda} \quad \text { and } \quad \mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \nu}^{\star} \nu(\bar{x}) \leq c_{\Lambda}, \quad \forall \bar{x} \in F
$$

with $c_{\Lambda}$ depending only on $c_{1}, c_{5}, L$ and $\delta_{0}$.
Hence, if we choose such a $\Lambda$, we have $\left\|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \varepsilon} \nu\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\mu)} \lesssim 1$ and $\left\|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \varepsilon}^{\star} \nu\right\|_{L^{\infty}(\mu)} \lesssim 1$ uniformly on $\varepsilon>0$. So we are left to verify the weak boundedness property for cubes with $M$-thin boundary contained in the parallelepipeds presented at the beginning of this subsection. In order to do it we will need two auxiliary results, similar to those found in [MPr, §3].

Lemma 5.14. Let $\varphi$ be a function supported on a cube $Q \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ with $\|\varphi\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. Then, $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)$ is a locally integrable function and moreover, if $\mu(Q) \lesssim \ell(Q)^{n}$, there exists $\bar{x}_{0} \in \frac{1}{4} Q$ and a constant $c_{0}$ such that

$$
\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right| \leq c_{0}
$$

Proof. In [MPr, Lemma 3.5], the authors deal with general distributions with $n$-growth. In our statement, however, $\nu$ is a specified signed measure and the cubes $Q$ satisfy the additional growth condition $\mu(Q) \lesssim \ell(Q)^{n}$. To prove the local integrability of $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)$, let us fix $\bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and name $I_{Q}:=\left\{j=1, \ldots, N: Q \cap B_{j} \neq \varnothing\right\}$. We compute, bearing in mind Lemma 3.1:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})\right| & =\left|\sum_{j \in I_{Q}} \frac{\left\langle T_{0}, \varphi_{j}\right\rangle}{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(B_{j}\right)} \int_{Q \cap B_{j}} P_{\Lambda}(\bar{x}, \bar{y}) \varphi(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})\right| \\
& \lesssim \sum_{j \in I_{Q}} \frac{1}{r_{j}} \int_{Q \cap B_{j}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}}=: \sum_{j \in I_{Q}} \frac{1}{r_{j}} I_{j}(\bar{x})
\end{aligned}
$$

To study $I_{j}(\bar{x})$ we split the integral into the domain

$$
D_{1, j}:=Q \cap B_{j} \cap\left\{\bar{y}: 2|\bar{x}-\bar{y}| \geq \operatorname{diam}\left(B_{j} \cap Q\right)\right\}
$$

and its complementary $D_{2, j}:=\left(Q \cap B_{j}\right) \backslash D_{1}$. For the first domain of integration we directly have

$$
\int_{D_{1, j}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}} \lesssim \frac{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(D_{1, j}\right)}{\operatorname{diam}\left(B_{j} \cap Q\right)^{n}} \leq \operatorname{diam}\left(B_{j} \cap Q\right) \leq r_{j}
$$

For the second one notice that

$$
D_{2, j}=Q \cap B_{j} \cap\left\{\bar{y}: 2|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|<\operatorname{diam}\left(B_{j} \cap Q\right)\right\} \subset B_{3 \operatorname{diam}\left(B_{j} \cap Q\right)}(\bar{x})
$$

Therefore, considering the annuli $A_{k}:=B_{2^{-k} 3 \operatorname{diam}\left(B_{j} \cap Q\right)}(\bar{x}) \backslash B_{2^{-k-1} 3 \operatorname{diam}\left(B_{j} \cap Q\right)}(\bar{x})$ for $k \geq 0$ we obtain

$$
\int_{D_{2, j}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}} \lesssim \sum_{k \geq 0} \int_{A_{k}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{y})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}} \lesssim \operatorname{diam}\left(B_{j} \cap Q\right) \sum_{k \geq 0} \frac{1}{2^{k}} \leq r_{j}
$$

Hence

$$
\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})\right| \lesssim\left|I_{Q}\right|<N<\infty
$$

and thus the local integrability of $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)$ follows. To prove the second assertion, we use $\mu(Q) \lesssim \ell(Q)^{n}$ together with Tonelli's theorem and Lemma 3.1 to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{Q}\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})\right| \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x}) & =\int_{Q}\left|\int_{F \cap Q} P_{\Lambda}(\bar{x}, \bar{y}) \varphi(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x}) \\
& \leq \int_{F \cap Q}\left(\int_{Q} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x})}{|\bar{x}-\bar{y}|^{n}}\right)|\varphi(\bar{y})| \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \leq \ell(Q) \int_{F \cap Q}|\varphi(\bar{y})| \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \\
& \leq \ell(Q) \mu(Q) \lesssim \ell(Q)^{n+1}=\mathcal{L}^{n+1}(Q)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\frac{1}{\mathcal{L}^{n+1}\left(\frac{1}{4} Q\right)} \int_{\frac{1}{4} Q}\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})\right| \mathrm{d} \mathcal{L}^{n+1}(\bar{x}) \lesssim 1
$$

and the desired result follows.

With the above lemma, we are able to prove a weaker localization-type result for $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}$, analogous to [MPr, Theorem 3.1]. It will be valid for our particular signed measure $\nu$ and cubes contained in $F \backslash H$. Recall that the latter inclusion implies, by property 6 in Lemma 5.3, that for any $\bar{x} \in Q$, if $R(\bar{x})$ is the cube centered at $\bar{x}$ with side length $\ell(R)$, then $\mu(\lambda R(\bar{x})) \leq \sqrt{n+1} L \ell(\lambda R)^{n} \simeq \ell(\lambda R)^{n}$, for any $\lambda>0$.

Lemma 5.15. Let $Q \subset F \backslash H$ be a cube and $\varphi$ a test function with $0 \leq \varphi \leq 1,\|\nabla \varphi\|_{\infty} \leq$ $\ell(Q)^{-1}$ and such that $\varphi \equiv 1$ on $Q$ and $\varphi \equiv 0$ on $(2 Q)^{c}$. Then,

$$
\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})\right| \lesssim 1, \quad \forall \bar{x} \in Q
$$

Proof. Let us fix any $\bar{x} \in Q$ and consider $\bar{x}_{0} \in \frac{1}{2} Q$ the point obtained in Lemma 5.14. Observe that $\varphi(\bar{x})=\varphi\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)=1$. We rewrite $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\cdot)$ as follows

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\cdot)= & \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 4 Q} P_{\Lambda}(\cdot, \bar{y})(\varphi(\bar{y})-\varphi(\bar{x})) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y}) \\
& +\int_{4 Q} P_{\Lambda}(\cdot, \bar{y})(\varphi(\bar{y})-\varphi(\bar{x})) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})+\varphi(\bar{x}) \int P_{\Lambda}(\cdot, \bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})
\end{aligned}
$$

and we apply this decomposition to $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})$ and $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$. Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})-\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right| \\
& \leq\left|\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 4 Q}\left(P_{\Lambda}(\bar{x}, \bar{y})-P_{\Lambda}\left(\bar{x}_{0}, y\right)\right)(\varphi(\bar{y})-\varphi(\bar{x})) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \\
& \quad+\left|\int_{4 Q} P_{\Lambda}(\bar{x}, \bar{y})(\varphi(\bar{y})-\varphi(\bar{x})) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})\right|+\left|\int_{4 Q} P_{\Lambda}\left(\bar{x}_{0}, \bar{y}\right)(\varphi(\bar{y})-\varphi(\bar{x})) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \\
& \quad+\left|\varphi(\bar{x}) \int P_{\Lambda}(\bar{x}, \bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})\right|+\left|\varphi(\bar{x}) \int P_{\Lambda}\left(\bar{x}_{0}, \bar{y}\right) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})\right|=: I_{1}+I_{2}+I_{3}+I_{4}+I_{5}
\end{aligned}
$$

Regarding $I_{4}$, observe that Lemma 5.13 implies

$$
|\varphi(\bar{x})|\left|\int P_{\Lambda}(\bar{x}, \bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})\right|=\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda} \nu(\bar{x})\right| \lesssim 1
$$

The same estimate holds for $I_{5}$. To study $I_{2}$ observe that

$$
\left|\int_{4 Q} P_{\Lambda}(\bar{x}, \bar{y})(\varphi(\bar{y})-\varphi(x)) \mathrm{d} \nu(\bar{y})\right| \leq c_{1}\|\nabla \varphi\|_{\infty} \int_{4 Q} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mu(\bar{y})}{\left|\bar{x}-\bar{y}\right|^{n-1}} \lesssim 1
$$

where we have used that $\bar{x} \in Q \subset F \backslash H$, so that we are able to integrate over decreasing annuli using the $n$-growth of $\mu$ for cubes centered at $\bar{x}$. The same holds for $I_{3}$ because $\bar{x}_{0} \in \frac{1}{2} Q$ and $\varphi(\bar{x})=\varphi\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$, so that $I_{3} \lesssim 1$. Finally, for $I_{1}$ we apply property 2 of Lemma 3.1 and integrate over increasing annuli to deduce

$$
I_{1} \lesssim 2 \ell(Q)\|\varphi\|_{\infty} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 4 Q} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \mu(\bar{y})}{\left|\bar{x}-\bar{y}\right|^{n+1}} \lesssim 1
$$

Therefore, $\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})\right| \leq\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})-\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}\left(\varphi \nu\right)\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right|+\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right| \lesssim 1$, and the desired result follows.

The previous lemma implies the main result of this subsection, which concerns a particular weak boundedness property for $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}$. We call it property 8 , in the sense that it is the additional property needed in Lemma 5.3 in order to apply a $T b$-theorem.

Corollary 5.16 (Property 8). Let $Q \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a cube contained in $F \backslash H$ with $M$-thin boundary. Then,

$$
\left|\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}\left(\chi_{Q} b\right),\left(\chi_{Q} b\right)\right\rangle\right| \leq c_{8} \mu(2 Q)
$$

for some $c_{8}>0$ constant.
Proof. Fix a cube $Q \subset F \backslash H$. We shall assume that $Q$ is open, since the involved measures $\mu$ and $\nu$ are null on sets of zero Lebesgue measure. Observe that since the center of $Q$ does not belong to $H$, in particular we have $\mu(2 Q) \lesssim L \ell(2 Q)^{n}$. Take a test function $\varphi$ with $0 \leq \varphi \leq 1,\|\nabla \varphi\|_{\infty} \leq \ell(Q)^{-1}$ and such that $\varphi \equiv 1$ on $Q$ and $\varphi \equiv 0$ on $(2 Q)^{c}$. Then,

$$
\left|\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}\left(\chi_{Q} b\right),\left(\chi_{Q} b\right)\right\rangle\right| \leq\left|\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}(\varphi b),\left(\chi_{Q} b\right)\right\rangle\right|+\left|\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}\left(\left(\varphi-\chi_{Q}\right) b\right),\left(\chi_{Q} b\right)\right\rangle\right|=: A+B
$$

To estimate $A$ we observe that $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}(\varphi b)=\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)$ and apply directly Lemma 5.15 to deduce $A \leq c_{1} \int_{Q}\left|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\varphi \nu)(\bar{x})\right| \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{x}) \lesssim \mu(Q)$.

To estimate $B$, set $\varphi_{1}:=\left(\varphi-\chi_{Q}\right) b$ and $\varphi_{2}:=\chi_{Q} b$. Observe that $\operatorname{supp}\left(\varphi_{1}\right) \subset \overline{2 Q} \backslash Q \subset$ $\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash Q$ and $\operatorname{supp}\left(\varphi_{2}\right) \subset \bar{Q}$. We now apply [To3, Lemma 5.23] with $\Omega_{1}:=Q$ and $\Omega_{2}:=\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash \overline{\Omega_{1}}$. The proof of the previous result is almost identical in our context: one just needs to change the function $d(\bar{x})^{-1 / 2}$ appearing in the previous reference by $d(\bar{x})^{-n / 2}$. In any case, we deduce

$$
B \lesssim\left\|\varphi_{1}\right\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}\left\|\varphi_{2}\right\|_{L^{2}(\mu)} \leq c_{1} \mu(\overline{2 Q} \backslash Q)^{1 / 2} \mu(\bar{Q})^{1 / 2} \leq c_{1} \mu(2 Q)
$$

and we are done.
The previous corollary suffices to prove an analogous $T b$-theorem to that of [To3, Ch.5], since the weak boundedness property needs only to be applied to cubes contained in parallelepipeds $\Delta:=P \cap S$ with $P, S$ cubes having $M$-thin boundary (and all their dyadic children too) that belong to $\mathcal{D}_{1}:=\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)$ and $\mathcal{D}_{2}:=\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)$ respectively for some $\bar{w}_{1}, \bar{w}_{2} \in$ $\Omega$. Moreover, $P \subset F \backslash\left(H_{\mathcal{D}_{1}} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}\right)$ and $S \subset F \backslash\left(H_{\mathcal{D}_{2}} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}\right)$. Therefore, since in particular $H \subset H_{\mathcal{D}_{1}} \cap H_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}$, the cubes contained in $\Delta$ do not intersect $H$. Hence, Corollary 5.16 can be applied to such cubes, yielding the following result:

Theorem 5.17. Let $\mu$ be a positive finite Borel measure on $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ supported on a compact set $F \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. Assume there is a finite measure $\nu$ and, for each $\bar{w} \in \Omega$, two subsets $H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}, T_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ consisting of dyadic cubes in $\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})$ so that:

1. $\nu=b \mu$ for some $b$ with $\|b\|_{\infty} \leq c_{b}$.
2. Every ball satisfying $\mu\left(B_{r}\right)>L r^{n}$ is contained in $\bigcap_{\bar{w} \in \Omega} H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}$.
3. If $Q \in \mathcal{D}(\bar{w})$ is such that $Q \not \subset T_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}$, then $\mu(Q) \leq c_{T}|\nu(Q)|$.
4. $\mu\left(H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}\right) \leq \delta_{0} \mu(F)$, for some $\delta_{0} \in(0,1)$.
5. If $\mathcal{P}_{\nu, *}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{\nu, *}^{*}$ denote the maximal convolution operators associated and $P$ and $P^{*}$ respectively with respect to $\nu$, we have for each $\bar{w} \in \Omega$,

$$
\int_{F \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}} \mathcal{P}_{*} \nu(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \leq c_{*} \mu(F), \quad \int_{F \backslash H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}} \mathcal{P}_{*}^{*} \nu(\bar{y}) \mathrm{d} \mu(\bar{y}) \leq c_{*} \mu(F)
$$

6. Let $Q \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a cube contained in $F \backslash \bigcap_{\bar{w} \in \Omega} H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}$ with $M$-thin boundary, and $\Lambda: \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \rightarrow[0, \infty)$ a 1-Lipschitz function satisfying

$$
\Lambda(\bar{x}) \geq \operatorname{dist}\left\{\bar{x}, \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash\left(H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})} \cup \mathcal{S}\right)\right), \quad \forall \bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}
$$

where $\mathcal{S}$ is the exceptional set defined in (5.13). Then,

$$
\left|\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}\left(\chi_{Q} b\right),\left(\chi_{Q} b\right)\right\rangle\right| \leq c_{W} \mu(2 Q)
$$

where $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}$ is the operator associated to the suppressed kernel $P_{\Lambda}$ defined in (3.1).
Then, there is $G \subset F \backslash \bigcap_{\bar{w} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}}\left(H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}\right)$ compact, and positive constants $A_{1}, A_{2}$ and $A_{3}$ so that
i. $\mu(F) \leq A_{1} \mu(G)$,
ii. $\left.\mu\right|_{G}\left(B_{r}(\bar{x})\right) \leq A_{2} r^{n}$, for every ball $B_{r}(\bar{x})$,
iii. $\left\|\mathcal{P}_{\mu \mid G}\right\|_{L^{2}\left(\mu \mid G\right) \rightarrow L^{2}\left(\mu \mid G\right)} \leq A_{3}$.

The letters $c_{b}, L, c_{T}, \delta_{0}, c_{*}, c_{W}$ and $M$ denote constants.
Remark 5.3. Let us give some details on how to prove Theorem 5.17, although the arguments to follow are just those given in the proofs of [To3, Theorem 5.1] or [Vo, Theorem 7.1], using, essentially, the weak boundedness property instead of the anti-symmetry of the Cauchy and Riesz kernels. Let us recall that we wrote, for $N \geq 4$ integer,

$$
\Omega:=\left[-2^{N-1}, 2^{N-1}\right)^{n+1}
$$

Fix $\bar{w} \in \Omega$. Recall $F \subset Q^{0}(\bar{w}):=\bar{w}+\left[-2^{N}, 2^{N}\right)^{n+1}$. A dyadic cube $Q \in Q^{0}(\bar{w})$ with $\mu(Q) \neq 0$ is called terminal if $Q \subset H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})} \cup T_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}$ and we write $Q \in \mathcal{D}^{\text {term }}(\bar{w})$. Otherwise is called transit and we write $Q \in \mathcal{D}^{\text {tr }}(\bar{w})$. With this, one considers a martingale decomposition of a function $f \in L_{\text {loc }}^{1}(\mu)$ in terms of $Q^{0}(\bar{w})$. For any cube $Q \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ with $\mu(Q) \neq 0$ one sets

$$
\langle f\rangle_{Q}:=\frac{1}{\mu(Q)} \int_{Q} f \mathrm{~d} \mu
$$

and defines the operator

$$
\Xi f:=\frac{\langle f\rangle_{Q^{0}(\bar{w})}}{\langle b\rangle_{Q^{0}(\bar{w})}} b
$$

It is clear that $\Xi f \in L^{2}(\mu)$ if $f \in L^{2}(\mu)$ and $\Xi^{2}=\Xi$. Moreover, the definition of $\Xi$ does not depend on the choice of $\bar{w} \in \Omega$.

If $Q \in \mathcal{D}(\bar{w})$, the set of at most $2^{n+1}$ dyadic children of $Q$ whose $\mu$-measure is not null is denoted by $\mathcal{C H}(Q)$. For any $Q \in \mathcal{D}^{\text {tr }}(\bar{w})$ and $f \in L_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1}(\mu)$ we define the function $\Delta_{Q} f$ as

$$
\Delta_{Q} f:=\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
0 & \text { in } \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash \bigcup_{R \in \mathcal{C H}(Q)} R \\
\left(\frac{\langle f\rangle_{R}}{\langle b\rangle_{R}}-\frac{\langle f\rangle_{Q}}{\langle b\rangle_{Q}}\right) b & \text { in } R \text { if } R \in \mathcal{C H}(Q) \cap \mathcal{D}^{\text {tr }}(\bar{w}) \\
f-\frac{\langle f\rangle_{Q}}{\langle b\rangle_{Q}} b & \text { in } R \text { if } R \in \mathcal{C H}(Q) \cap \mathcal{D}^{\text {term }}(\bar{w})
\end{array}\right.
$$

The fundamental properties of the operators $\Xi$ and $\Delta_{Q}$ are proved in [To3, Lemmas 5.10, 5.11] and, essentially, allow to decompose $f \in L^{2}(\mu)$ as

$$
f=\Xi f+\sum_{Q \in \mathcal{D}^{\text {tr }}} \Delta_{Q} f
$$

where the sum is unconditionally convergent in $L^{2}(\mu)$ and, in addition,

$$
\|f\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}^{2} \approx\|\Xi f\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}^{2}+\sum_{Q \in \mathcal{D}^{\text {tr }}}\left\|\Delta_{Q} f\right\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}^{2}
$$

At this point, one of the fundamental steps of the proof of the $T b$-theorem consists in using the above decomposition to estimate the $L^{2}(\mu)$ norm of the suppressed operator $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}$ when applied to the so called good functions. To define them, we need to introduce first good and bad cubes. Let $\bar{w}_{1}, \bar{w}_{2} \in \Omega$ and consider $\mathcal{D}_{1}:=\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right), \mathcal{D}_{2}:=\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)$ two dyadic lattices. We consider as in [NTVo2, Definition 6.2] the parameter

$$
\alpha:=\frac{1}{2(n+1)}
$$

and we will say that $Q \in \mathcal{D}_{1}^{\text {tr }}$ is bad with respect to $\mathcal{D}_{2}$ if either

1. there is $R \in \mathcal{D}_{2}^{\text {tr }}$ such that $\operatorname{dist}(Q, \partial R) \leq \ell(Q)^{\alpha} \ell(R)^{1-\alpha}$ and $\ell(R) \geq 2^{m} \ell(Q)$, for some positive integer $m$ to be fixed later, or
2. there is $R \in \mathcal{D}_{2}^{\text {tr }}$ such that $2^{-m} \ell(Q) \leq \ell(R) \leq 2^{m} \ell(Q), \operatorname{dist}(Q, R) \leq 2^{m} \ell(Q)$ and, at least, one of the children of $R$ does not have $M$-thin boundary.

If $Q$ is not bad, then we say that it is good with respect to $\mathcal{D}_{2}$. An important property regarding bad cubes is that they do not appear very often in dyadic lattices. More precisely, given $\varepsilon_{b}>0$ arbitrarily small, if $m$ and $M$ are chosen big enough, then for each fixed $Q \in \mathcal{D}_{1}$, the probability that it is bad with respect to $\mathcal{D}_{2}$ is not larger than $\varepsilon_{b}$. That is,

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\left\{\bar{w}_{2} \in \Omega: Q \in \mathcal{D}_{1} \text { is bad with respect to } \mathcal{D}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)\right\}\right) \leq \varepsilon_{b}
$$

In light of the above notions, we say that a function $f \in L^{2}(\mu)$ is $\mathcal{D}_{1}$-good with respect to $\mathcal{D}_{2}$ if $\Delta_{Q} f=0$ for all bad cubes $Q \in \mathcal{D}_{1}^{\text {tr }}$ (with respect to $\mathcal{D}_{2}$ ). Now one proceeds as follows: define the 1-Lipschitz function

$$
\Lambda_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}(\bar{x}):=\operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{x}, \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash W_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}\right), \quad \bar{w} \in \Omega
$$

It satisfies $\Lambda_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}(\bar{x}) \geq \operatorname{dist}\left(\bar{x}, \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash\left(H_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})} \cup \mathcal{S}\right)\right)$, so that Lemma 5.13 can be applied to $\Lambda_{\mathcal{D}(\bar{w})}$, and then we have:

Lemma 5.18. ([To3, Lemma 5.13]) Let $\mathcal{D}_{1}=\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)$ and $\mathcal{D}_{2}=\mathcal{D}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)$ with $\bar{w}_{1}, \bar{w}_{2} \in \Omega$. Given $\varepsilon>0$, let $\Lambda: \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \rightarrow[\varepsilon, \infty)$ be a 1-Lipschitz function such that

$$
\Lambda(\bar{x}) \geq \max \left\{\Lambda_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}(\bar{x}), \Lambda_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}(\bar{x})\right\}, \quad \forall \bar{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}
$$

Then, if $f \in L^{2}(\mu)$ is $\mathcal{D}_{1}$-good with respect to $\mathcal{D}_{2}$ and $g \in L^{2}(\mu)$ is $\mathcal{D}_{2}$-good with respect to $\mathcal{D}_{1}$,

$$
\left|\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(f \mu), g\right\rangle\right| \lesssim\|f\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}\|g\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}
$$

where the implicit constant depends on $c_{b}, L, c_{T}, \delta_{0}, c_{*}, c_{W}$ and $\varepsilon_{b}$, but not on $\varepsilon$.
The proof of this result uses the above martingale decomposition of the functions $f, g$, so that one is left to estimate:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(f \mu), g\right\rangle=\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\Xi f \mu), \Xi g\right\rangle+\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\Xi f \mu), g\right\rangle & +\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(f \mu), \Xi g\right\rangle \\
& +\sum_{Q \in \mathcal{D}_{1}^{G}, R \in \mathcal{D}_{2}^{G}}\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}\left(\left(\Delta_{Q} f\right) \mu\right), \Delta_{R} g\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

If our kernel were anti-symmetric, the first term of the right-hand side would be null. Although this is not our case, it can still be estimated as follows (notice that the weak boundedness property will not be used in the arguments below):

$$
\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\Xi f \mu), \Xi g\right\rangle \leq\left\|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\Xi f \mu)\right\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}\|\Xi g\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}
$$

Observe that $\operatorname{supp}(\mu) \subset F \subset Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right) \cap Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)$ and by definition

$$
\Xi g:=\frac{\langle g\rangle_{Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)}}{\langle b\rangle_{Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)}} b
$$

This implies, since $Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)$ is always a transit cube (this is easy to see just arguing by contradiction and using assumption 4 in Theorem 5.17),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\Xi g\|_{L^{2}(\mu)} & \leq \frac{\mu\left(Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)\right)^{1 / 2}}{\left|\nu\left(Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)\right)\right|}\left(\int_{F}|b|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu\right)^{1 / 2}\|g\|_{L^{2}(\mu)} \\
& \leq c_{T}^{1 / 2}\left(\frac{1}{\left|\nu\left(Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{2}\right)\right)\right|} \int_{F}|b|^{2} \mathrm{~d} \mu\right)^{1 / 2}\|g\|_{L^{2}(\mu)} \leq c_{1} c_{T}\|g\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, by Lemma 5.13 and using that $Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)$ is a transit cube, we deduce

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\Xi f \mu)\right\|_{L^{2}(\mu)} & =\frac{\left|\left\langle f\rangle_{Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)}\right|}{\left|\left\langle b\rangle_{Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)}\right|}\left\|\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(b \mu)\right\|_{L^{2}(\mu)} \leq c_{\Lambda} \frac{\left|\left\langle f\rangle_{Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)}\right|}{\left|\left\langle b\rangle_{Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)}\right|\right.} \mu\left(Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)\right)^{1 / 2} \\
& \leq c_{\Lambda} c_{T}\left|\left\langle f\rangle_{Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)}\right| \mu\left(Q^{0}\left(\bar{w}_{1}\right)\right)^{1 / 2} \leq c_{\Lambda} c_{T}\|f\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence

$$
\left|\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\Xi f \mu), \Xi g\right\rangle\right| \lesssim\|f\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}\|g\|_{L^{2}(\mu)}
$$

The terms $\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(\Xi f \mu), g\right\rangle$ and $\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}(f \mu), \Xi g\right\rangle$ can be estimated similarly (see [To3, p. 155]), and it is important to notice that to do so one uses Lemma 5.13 for the adjoint suppressed operator $\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}^{*}$. Hence, the only term left is

$$
\sum_{Q \in \mathcal{D}_{1}^{G}, R \in \mathcal{D}_{2}^{G}}\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda}\left(\left(\Delta_{Q} f\right) \mu\right), \Delta_{R} g\right\rangle
$$

The above sum is studied in [To3, $\S 5.6, \S 5.7, \S 5.8 \& \S 5.9]$, and the arguments can be followed analogously up to [To3, §5.9]. Obviously, there are changes that need to be done regarding the dimensionality. Such modifications were already done in a general

multidimensional setting in the study carried out in [Vo] for Riesz kernels. In any case, it is in [To3, §5.9] where the weak boundedness property needs to be invoked in order to deal with expressions of the form

$$
\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}\left(\chi_{\Delta} b\right),\left(\chi_{\Delta} b\right)\right\rangle
$$

where $\Delta$ is a certain parallelepiped introduced at the beginning of Subsection 5.4. Such expressions were already tackled in [NTVo2] or [HyMar], and they can be deduced from the estimate

$$
\left|\left\langle\mathcal{P}_{\Lambda, \mu}\left(\chi_{Q} b\right),\left(\chi_{Q} b\right)\right\rangle\right| \lesssim \mu(2 Q)
$$

where in our setting we may assume $Q$ to be contained in $F \backslash H$ and with $M$-thin boundary. This precise bound is covered by assumption 6 in the statement of Theorem 5.17. From this point on, the rest of the proof can be followed as in the remaining sections of [To3, Ch.5] to obtain the desired result. Let us also remark that the proof can be followed almost identically (apart from some dimensional changes) taking into account that we have constructed unique measures $\mu$ and $\nu$ so that assumption 5 holds for the operators $\mathcal{P}$ and $\mathcal{P}^{*}$ simultaneously. This enables to obtain relation (5.14), which is essential to carry out the final probabilistic arguments in the proof of the $T b$-theorem found in [To3, Ch.5] or [Vo].

In any case, in light of Theorem 5.17 and also bearing in mind the argument of (5.4) and that assumptions $\mathbf{A}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{A}_{2}$ are superfluous, we have proved the following:

Theorem 5.19. Let $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a compact set satisfying $\mathbf{A}_{3}$. Then,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E)
$$

# 6. Some general comparability results. The semi-additivity of $\widetilde{\gamma}$ in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ 

The main goal of this section is to obtain similar results to Theorem 5.19 but removing assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$. We will be able to do this for any compact set in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ and for a certain family of sets in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$, which in particular contains the usual corner-like Cantor sets presented in $[\mathrm{He}]$.
6.1. The capacity of some parallelepipeds in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. First, let us present some preliminary results that extend that of [MPr, Proposition 6.1]. Let us remark that throughout the forthcoming discussion, any parallelepiped will be closed and will have sides parallel to the coordinate axes.

Lemma 6.1. Let $a \in \mathbb{R}$ and $R \subset \mathbb{R}^{n} \times\{a\}$ be a parallelepiped contained in the affine hyperplane $\{t=a\}$. Then

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(R) \gtrsim \mathcal{H}^{n}(R)
$$

Proof. Let $\mu:=\left.\mathcal{H}^{n}\right|_{R}$ and pick any $\bar{x}=(x, t)$ with $|t-a|>0$. Observe that

$$
P_{a y} * \mu(x, t)=\int_{R} \frac{|t-a|}{\left[(t-a)^{2}+|x-y|^{2}\right]^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} \mathrm{~d} \mathcal{H}^{n}(y)=\int_{R-x} \frac{|t-a|}{\left[(t-a)^{2}+|u|^{2}\right]^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} \mathrm{~d} \mathcal{H}^{n}(u)
$$

where $u:=y-x$ and $R-x$ denotes a translation of $R$ with respect to the vector $(-x, 0) \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. Let us pick $D_{r_{0}}$ an $n$-dimensional ball embedded in $\mathbb{R}^{n} \times\{a\}$, centered at $(0, a) \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{n} \times\{a\}$ and with radius $r_{0}=r_{0}(\bar{x})$ big enough so that $R-x \subset D_{r_{0}}$. Then, there exists a dimensional constant $C>0$ so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{\mathrm{sy}} * \mu(x, t) & \leq \int_{D_{r_{0}}} \frac{|t-a|}{\left[(t-a)^{2}+|u|^{2}\right]^{\frac{n+1}{2}} \mathrm{~d} \mathcal{H}^{n}(u)}=C \int_{0}^{r_{0}} \frac{|t-a|}{\left[(t-a)^{2}+r^{2}\right]^{\frac{n+1}{2}} r^{n-1} \mathrm{~d} r} \\
& =C \int_{0}^{1} \frac{|t-a| r_{0}^{-1}}{\left[(t-a)^{2} r_{0}^{-2}+\rho^{2}\right]^{\frac{n+1}{2}} \rho^{n-1} \mathrm{~d} \rho}
\end{aligned}
$$

where in the last step we have introduced the change of variables $r_{0} \rho=r$. Naming $\tau:=|t-a| r_{0}^{-1}$ the previous integral can be finally written as

$$
\int_{0}^{1} \frac{\tau}{\left[\tau^{2}+\rho^{2}\right]^{\frac{n+1}{2}} \rho^{n-1} \mathrm{~d} \rho}
$$

which admits an explicit representation in terms of Gauss's (or Kummer's) hypergeometric function (use [Bu, §1.4, eq.(13)], for example), obtaining the estimate

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{\mathrm{sy}} * \mu(x, t) & \leq \frac{C}{n}\left(\frac{\rho}{\tau}\right)^{n}{ }_{2} F_{1}\left(\frac{n}{2}, \frac{n+1}{2} ; \frac{n+2}{2} ;-\left.\left(\frac{\rho}{\tau}\right)^{2}\right)\right|_{\rho=0} ^{\rho=1} \\
& =\frac{C}{n} \cdot \frac{1}{\tau^{n}}{ }_{2} F_{1}\left(\frac{n}{2}, \frac{n+1}{2} ; \frac{n+2}{2} ;-\frac{1}{\tau^{2}}\right) \\
& =\frac{C}{n} \cdot \frac{1}{\tau\left(1+\tau^{2}\right)^{(n-1) / 2}}{ }_{2} F_{1}\left(1, \frac{1}{2} ; \frac{n+2}{2} ;-\frac{1}{\tau^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In the last step we have applied [AbS, Eq.15.3.3]. This last expression, thought as a function of $\tau>0$, is bounded uniformly on $(0,+\infty)$ with respect to a dimensional constant (and in fact attains its maximum when $\tau \rightarrow 0$ ). In other words, we deduce that $P_{\text {sy }} *$ $\mu(x, t) \lesssim 1$ whenever $|t-a|>0$. On the other hand, it is clear that if $t=a$, then $P_{\text {sy }} * \mu(x, t)=0$, meaning that in general

$$
P_{\mathrm{sy}} * \mu(x, t) \lesssim 1, \quad \forall(x, t) \in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}
$$

Therefore we conclude

$$
\gamma_{\mathrm{sy},+}(R) \gtrsim \mu(R)=\mathcal{H}^{n}(R)
$$

and using Theorem 3.5 we obtain the desired result.
The above lemma characterizes the $\widetilde{\gamma}_{+}$capacity of parallelepipeds contained in affine hyperplanes of the form $\{t=a\}$. We will refer to such hyperplanes as horizontal hyperplanes. Observe that the above bound combined with [MPr, Lemma 4.1] implies

$$
\mathcal{H}^{n}(R) \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E) \leq \gamma_{+}(R) \leq \gamma(R) \lesssim \mathcal{H}_{\infty}^{n}(R) \leq \mathcal{H}^{n}(R)
$$

for any parallelepiped contained in a horizontal hyperplane. Hence, for such objects,

$$
\mathcal{H}^{n}(R) \approx \gamma_{+}(R) \approx \gamma(R)
$$

Our next goal will be to study the capacity associated to parallelepipeds contained in vertical hyperplanes, that is, sets of the form $\left\{x_{i}=a\right\}$ for some $a \in \mathbb{R}$ and some $i=$ $1, \ldots, n$. Previous to that, we need to make an auxiliary construction: let us assume that

we have a compact set $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ contained, for example, in $\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$. Consider $T$ a distribution in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ with $\operatorname{supp}(T) \subseteq E$ as well as the maps

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi: \quad \mathbb{R}^{n+1} & \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n}, & \iota: \mathbb{R}^{n} & \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \\
\left(x_{1}, x\right) & \longmapsto x & & x \longmapsto(0, x)
\end{aligned}
$$

the canonical projection onto the last $n$ coordinates and the canonical inclusion into the hyperplane $\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$. Let us take $\varphi \in \mathcal{C}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ a smooth function and define $\beta_{M}$, for some $M>0$ (a positive parameter that we may take as large as we need), a smooth bump function in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ that equals 1 in an open $M$-neighborhood of $E$, i.e. $\beta_{M} \equiv 1$ in $\mathcal{U}_{M}(E)$. Also, we require that $\beta_{M} \equiv 0$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash \mathcal{U}_{2 M}(E)$ and $0 \leq \beta_{M} \leq 1$. We set

$$
\widetilde{\varphi}:=(\varphi \circ \pi) \cdot \beta_{M}
$$

that is a smooth extension of $\left.\varphi\right|_{E}$ to $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$, with compact support contained in $\mathcal{U}_{2 M}(E)$. With this, we define the following distribution in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ associated to $T$ :

$$
\langle\widetilde{T}, \varphi\rangle:=\langle T, \widetilde{\varphi}\rangle, \quad \varphi \in \mathcal{C}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)
$$

which is a definition independent of the choice of $\beta_{M}$, since $\operatorname{supp}(T) \subseteq E$. Observe that $\operatorname{supp}(\widetilde{T}) \subseteq \pi(E)$ (a compact set of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ ) and also that for any $\psi \in \mathcal{C}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$,

$$
\langle T, \psi\rangle=\langle\widetilde{T}, \psi \circ \iota\rangle
$$

Notice that the previous identity is accurate because, even though $\psi$ and $\psi \circ \iota \circ \pi$ may not coincide in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$, we have $\operatorname{supp}(T) \subseteq E \subset\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$, that ensures the validity of the above equality. Let us take $\left(\Phi_{\varepsilon}\right)_{\varepsilon}$ an approximation of the identity in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ and set

$$
\widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon}:=\widetilde{T} * \Phi_{\varepsilon}
$$

for $0<\varepsilon \ll M$, so that the following inclusions hold

$$
\operatorname{supp}\left(\widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon}\right) \subseteq \mathcal{V}_{2 \varepsilon}(\pi(E)) \subset \pi\left(\mathcal{U}_{M}(E)\right)
$$

where the notation $\mathcal{V}$ is used to emphasize that we are considering an open neighborhood in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ and not $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. So $\left(\widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon}\right)_{\varepsilon}$ defines a collection of signed measures in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ that approximates $\widetilde{T}$ in a distributional sense:

$$
\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}\langle\widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon}, \varphi\rangle=\langle\widetilde{T}, \varphi\rangle=\langle T, \widetilde{\varphi}\rangle, \quad \varphi \in \mathcal{C}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)
$$

Let us stress (although the reader may have already noticed), that the spaces of functions we have been considering are of the form $\mathcal{C}^{\infty}$ and not $\mathcal{C}_{\varepsilon}^{\infty}$. This can be done since our distributions are compactly supported. Let us proceed by naming $\Sigma_{\varepsilon}:=\overline{\mathcal{V}_{2 \varepsilon}(\pi(E))}$, and observe that for any $\psi \in \mathcal{C}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\langle T, \psi\rangle=\langle\widetilde{T}, \psi \circ \iota\rangle & =\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} C \int_{\Sigma_{E}} \widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon}(x) \psi \circ \iota(x) \mathrm{d} \mathcal{H}^{n}(x) \\
& =\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} C \int_{\Sigma_{E}} \widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon} \circ \pi(0, x) \psi(0, x) \mathrm{d} \mathcal{H}^{n}(x) \\
& =\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0} C \int_{\mathbb{R}^{n+1}} \widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon} \circ \pi(\bar{x}) \psi(\bar{x})\left.\mathrm{d} \mathcal{H}^{n}\right|_{l\left(\Sigma_{E}\right)}(\bar{x}) \\
& =\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}\left\langle\left. C\left(\widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon} \circ \pi\right) \mathcal{H}^{n}\right|_{l\left(\Sigma_{\varepsilon}\right)}, \psi\right\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon} \circ \pi$ is smooth and supported on $\mathbb{R} \times \Sigma_{\varepsilon} \subset \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R}^{n}$, and $C>0$ is some dimensional constant. Therefore, the previous construction implies the following remark:

Remark 6.1. Given a distribution $T$ in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ supported on $E \subset\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$, there is a family of signed measures $\left(\nu_{\varepsilon}\right)_{\varepsilon}$ with $\operatorname{supp}\left(\nu_{\varepsilon}\right) \subset \iota\left(\Sigma_{\varepsilon}\right)=: \iota\left(\overline{\mathcal{V}}_{2 \varepsilon}(\pi(E))\right)$ of the form

$$
\nu_{\varepsilon}=\left.\psi_{\varepsilon} \cdot \mathcal{H}^{n}\right|_{\iota\left(\Sigma_{\varepsilon}\right)}
$$

where $\psi_{\varepsilon}$ is a smooth function that satisfies $\psi_{\varepsilon} \circ \iota=\widetilde{T}_{\varepsilon}$ (a function of $\mathcal{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ supported on $\left.\Sigma_{\varepsilon}\right)$, that is such that

$$
\langle T, \psi\rangle=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}\left\langle\nu_{\varepsilon}, \psi\right\rangle, \quad \psi \in \mathcal{C}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)
$$

The reader may think of the above result as a construction that exploits the fact that the support of $T$ is contained in a hyperplane where $x_{1}$ is constant, so that we may approximate $T$ via an approximation of the identity with respect to the remaining variables $x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n+1}$ (here $x_{n+1}=t$ ). Moreover, notice that if one starts assuming a condition of the form $\left\|P * T\right\|_{\infty} \leq 1$, by choosing $\varepsilon$ small enough we can assume, for example, $\left\|P * \nu_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 2$. Indeed, just fix any $\psi \in \mathcal{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$ and observe that

$$
\langle P * T, \psi\rangle=\left\langle T, P^{*} * \psi\right\rangle=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}\left\langle\nu_{\varepsilon}, P^{*} * \psi\right\rangle=\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}\left\langle P * \nu_{\varepsilon}, \psi\right\rangle
$$

meaning that $\lim _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0}\left|\left\langle P * \nu_{\varepsilon}, \psi\right\rangle\right| \leq\|\psi\|_{L^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)}$, which implies the desired estimate. In the previous argument we have used that $P^{*} * \psi$ is a smooth function, which can be argued thinking of $P^{*}$ as an $L_{\mathrm{loc}}^{1}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$ function and thus as a regular distribution. This allows us to prove the following lemma:

Lemma 6.2. Let $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a compact set contained in an affine hyperplane of the form $\left\{x_{i}=a\right\}$, for some $a \in \mathbb{R}$ and $i=1, \ldots, n$. Then

$$
\gamma(E)=0
$$

Proof. We shall assume that $E$ is contained in $\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$ for the sake of simplicity. Consider $D_{r_{0}}$ an $n$-dimensional ball in $\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$ centered at the origin and with radius $r_{0}$. Let us assume that $\gamma\left(D_{r_{0}}\right)>0$ and reach a contradiction. If $\gamma\left(D_{r_{0}}\right)>0$, there exists a distribution $T$ admissible for $\gamma_{i \text { ( } 0^{1 / 2}}\left(D_{r_{0}}\right)$ with $|\langle T, 1\rangle|>0$. By Remark 6.1 we obtain a family of signed measures that approximate $T$ of the form

$$
\nu_{\varepsilon}=\left.\psi_{\varepsilon} \cdot \mathcal{H}^{n}\right|_{D_{r_{0}+2 \varepsilon}}
$$

for some $\psi_{\varepsilon}$ smooth, such that $\psi_{\varepsilon} \circ \iota \in \mathcal{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n}\right)$ with $\operatorname{supp}\left(\psi_{\varepsilon} \circ \iota\right) \subset \pi\left(D_{r_{0}+2 \varepsilon}\right)$. We may also choose $\varepsilon$ small enough so that $\left\|P * \nu_{\varepsilon}\right\|_{\infty} \leq 2$. Since $|\langle T, 1\rangle|>0$, we are able to pick some $\bar{x}_{0}=\left(x_{0}, t_{0}\right) \in D_{r_{0}+2 \varepsilon}$ such that $\left|\psi_{\varepsilon}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right|>0$, as well as an $n$-dimensional ball centered at $\bar{x}_{0}$ with radius $\eta$ satisfying $D_{\eta}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \subset D_{r_{0}+2 \varepsilon}$ and $\left|\psi_{\varepsilon}\right| \geq A>0$ there, for some constant $A>0$ (this can be done by the continuity of $\psi_{\varepsilon} \circ \iota$ ).
Proceed by fixing $Q=Q\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$ a cube in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ centered at $\bar{x}_{0}$ with $4 \ell(Q) \leq \eta$ and $\varphi \in$ $\mathcal{C}_{c}^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\right)$ such that $0 \leq \varphi \leq 1,\left.\varphi\right|_{Q} \equiv 1,\left.\varphi\right|_{\mathbb{R}^{n+1} \backslash 2 Q} \equiv 0$ and $\|\nabla \varphi\|_{\infty} \leq \ell(Q)^{-1}$. Also take $B_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$ a ball in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ centered at $\bar{x}_{0}$ with radius $\xi$ so that $4 \xi \leq \ell(Q)$, and name $D_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right):=B_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \cap\left\{x_{1}=0\right\}$, that is such that

$$
D_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \subset Q\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right) \cap\left\{x_{1}=0\right\} \subset D_{\eta}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)
$$

We finally define the positive measure

$$
\left.\mu^{\prime}:=\left.A \cdot \mathcal{H}^{n}\right|_{D_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)}\right.
$$

and observe that by the choice of $\varphi$ and the non-negativity of $P$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|P * \mu^{\prime}\right\|_{\infty} & =\left\|P * A \mathcal{H}^{n}\right|_{D_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)}\left\|_{\infty}=\right\| P * \varphi A \mathcal{H}^{n}\left\|_{D_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)}\right\|_{\infty} \\
& \leq\left\|P * \varphi \psi_{\varepsilon} \mathcal{H}^{n}\right|_{D_{r_{0}+\bar{x}_{t}}}\left\|_{\infty}=\right\| P * \varphi \nu_{\varepsilon}\left\|_{\infty} \lesssim 1\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last inequality is due to the localization estimate [MPr, Theorem 3.1]. Therefore, we have constructed $D_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$ an $n$-dimensional ball that admits a positive measure $\mu$ supported on it, proportional to $\left.\mathcal{H}^{n}\right|_{D_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)}$ and with $\|P * \mu\|_{\infty} \leq 1$. Let us prove that this last condition is not possible. Indeed, for each $\bar{x}=\left(0, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{n}, t\right) \in D_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$ pick an $n$-dimensional ball $D_{\rho}(\bar{x})$ centered at $\bar{x}$ and with radius $\rho$ small enough so that $D_{\rho}(\bar{x}) \subset D_{\xi}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)$. We write $\Delta_{\downarrow, \rho}(\bar{x})$ its lower temporal half, which is obtained from the intersection $D_{\rho}(\bar{x}) \cap\{t-s>0\}$; as well as $\Delta_{\uparrow, \rho}(\bar{x})$ the upper temporal half, obtained from $D_{\rho}(\bar{x}) \cap\{t-s<0\}$. Now, integration in ( $n$-dimensional) spherical coordinates yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
P * \mu(\bar{x}) & \geq A \int_{\Delta_{\downarrow, \rho}(\bar{x})} \frac{t-s}{\left[(t-s)^{2}+\left(x_{2}-y_{2}\right)^{2}+\cdots+\left(x_{n}-y_{n}\right)^{2}\right]^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} \mathrm{~d} \mathcal{H}^{n}\left(y_{2}, \ldots, y_{n}, s\right) \\
& \simeq A \int_{\Delta_{\uparrow, \rho}(0)} \frac{\tau}{\left[\tau^{2}+u_{2}^{2}+\cdots+u_{n}^{2}\right]^{\frac{n+1}{2}}} \mathrm{~d} u_{2} \cdots \mathrm{~d} u_{n} \mathrm{~d} \tau=A \cdot L \int_{0}^{\rho} \frac{\mathrm{d} r}{r}=+\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

where $L$ is a positive dimensional constant obtained from integration in the angular domain (notice that $\tau>0$ in $\Delta_{\uparrow, \rho}(0)$ ). So by the arbitrariness of $\bar{x}$ we get that $\|P * \mu\|_{L^{\infty}(\mu)}=+\infty$, since $\mu\left(D_{\eta}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right) \simeq A \mathcal{H}^{n}\left(D_{\eta}\left(\bar{x}_{0}\right)\right)>0$. But this is contradictory with $\|P * \mu\|_{\infty} \leq 1$, because such condition implies, in particular, $\|P * \mu\|_{L^{\infty}(\mu)} \lesssim 1$ (use a Cotlar type inequality analogous to that of [MaP, Lemma 5.4]). Therefore we conclude that $\gamma\left(D_{r_{0}}\right)=0$ for any radius $r_{0}$, implying the desired result, by the monotonicity of $\gamma$.

Corollary 6.3. Let $R \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a parallelepiped and $\ell_{1}, \ldots, \ell_{n}, \ell_{t}$ its side lengths. Let $R_{\uparrow}$ denote the upper face of $R$ (contained in a horizontal affine hyperplane),

1) if $\gamma\left(R_{\uparrow}\right)=0$, then $\gamma(R)=0$,
2) if $\ell_{t} \leq \min \left\{\ell_{1}, \ldots, \ell_{n}\right\}$, then $\gamma(R) \approx \gamma_{+}\left(R_{\uparrow}\right)$.

Proof. To prove 1 , begin by noticing that $\gamma\left(R_{\uparrow}\right)=0$ implies $\mathcal{H}^{n}\left(R_{\uparrow}\right)=0$, by the comments made after Lemma 6.1. Embedding $R_{\uparrow}$ into $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ via $\pi_{x}: \mathbb{R}^{n+1} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{n}, \pi_{x}(\bar{x})=x$, the canonical projection onto the spatial coordinates; we deduce that $Q=\pi_{x}(R)$ is such that $\mathcal{L}^{n}(Q)=0$. But $Q$ is itself a parallelepiped of $\mathbb{R}^{n}$, i.e.

$$
Q=\left[a_{1}, b_{1}\right] \times \cdots \times\left[a_{n}, b_{n}\right], \quad \text { for some } a_{i}, b_{i} \in \mathbb{R}, a_{i} \leq b_{i}
$$

So there must exist some $\left[a_{j}, b_{j}\right]$ such that $a_{j}=b_{j}$. Hence,

$$
R=\left[a_{1}, b_{1}\right] \times \cdots \times\left[a_{j-1}, b_{j-1}\right] \times\left\{a_{j}\right\} \times\left[a_{j+1}, b_{j+1}\right] \times \cdots \times\left[a_{n+1}, b_{n+1}\right]
$$

and thus $R \subset\left\{x_{j}=a_{j}\right\}$, a vertical hyperplane. Applying Lemma 6.2 the result follows.
Moving on to 2, let us assume $\ell_{t}>0$ (if not the result is trivial) and notice that by [MPr, Lemma 4.1] and Lemma 6.1 we have

$$
\gamma(R) \lesssim \mathcal{H}_{\infty}^{n}(R) \lesssim\left[\frac{\ell_{1}}{\ell_{t}} \cdots \frac{\ell_{n}}{\ell_{t}} \cdot 1\right] \cdot \ell_{t}^{n} \simeq \mathcal{H}^{n}\left(R_{\uparrow}\right) \lesssim \gamma_{+}\left(R_{\uparrow}\right)
$$

and we are done.

6.2. General comparability for parallelepipeds in $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. In light of the above results, we shall obtain a first estimate analogous to Theorem 5.19 for parallelepipeds, where assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ will not be needed.

Lemma 6.4. Let $R \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ be a closed parallelepiped with sides parallel to the coordinate axes. Then,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(R) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(R)
$$

Proof. Let us denote by $\ell_{1}, \ldots, \ell_{n}, \ell_{t}$ the side lengths of $R$. Notice that by Lemmas 6.1 and 6.2 we already know the above result if any $\ell_{i}$ is null. So let us assume that

$$
\ell_{i}>0, \quad \text { for each } i=1, \ldots, n, t
$$

Moreover, we will also assume without loss of generality that $R$ is contained in $B_{1}(0)$, the unit ball of $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. The argument that follows is inspired by that presented in [Vo, Ch.6]. Let us begin by applying Theorem 4.1 to the compact set $E:=R$ to obtain a first family of cubes $\left\{\mathcal{Q}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{Q}_{N_{1}}\right\}$ satisfying properties $\mathbf{P}_{1}$ to $\mathbf{P}_{5}$. We observe that:

- Regarding property $\mathbf{P}_{4}$, if $\ell_{\max }:=\max \left\{\ell_{1}, \ldots, \ell_{n}, \ell_{t}\right\}$, we get for each $i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}$,

$$
\operatorname{diam}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right) \leq \frac{1}{10} \operatorname{diam}(R) \leq \frac{\sqrt{n+1}}{10} \ell_{\max } \quad \text { and then } \quad \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right) \leq \frac{1}{10} \ell_{\max }
$$

- Regarding $\mathbf{P}_{1}$, we get $\frac{5}{8} \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}} \cap R \neq \varnothing$ for each $i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}$. We wish to study the intersections $2 Q_{i_{1}} \cap R$ using the previous property. Notice that $\frac{5}{8} \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}} \cap R \neq \varnothing$ implies that the sets $2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}} \cap R$ are parallelepipeds such that their side with maximal length presents length between $\frac{11}{16} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)$ and $2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)$. On the other hand, we distinguish two cases for the sides with minimal length, depending on $\ell_{\min }:=\min \left\{\ell_{1}, \ldots, \ell_{n}, \ell_{t}\right\}$ :
A) If it happens

$$
\ell_{\min } \geq \frac{11}{16} \max _{i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}} \ell\left(Q_{i_{1}}\right)
$$

then the parallelepipeds $2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}} \cap R$ have minimal side length between $\frac{11}{16} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)$ and $2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)$.
B) If on the other hand

$$
\ell_{\min }<\frac{11}{16} \max _{i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)
$$

the parallelepipeds $2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}} \cap R$ have minimal side length bigger or equal than the quantity $\min \left\{\ell_{\min }, \frac{11}{16} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)\right\}$ and smaller or equal than $\min \left\{\ell_{\min }, 2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)\right\}$, for each $i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}$.

For each $i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}$ we call $R_{i_{1}}:=2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}} \cap R$ and consider two cases

1) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is satisfied for $E:=R$.
2) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is not satisfied for $E:=R$.

If 1) occurs we are done, by Theorem 5.19. If 2) occurs, notice that if $\mathbf{A})$ also occurs we get that $R_{1}, \ldots R_{N_{1}}$ are parallelepipeds such that all of their respective sides have comparable lengths. In other words, there exists a cube $S_{i_{1}} \subset R_{i_{1}}$ so that $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}\left(S_{i_{1}}\right)$,

for each $i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}$. Then, using that $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is not satisfied together with point 2 in Corollary 6.3, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widetilde{\gamma}(R)<C_{1}^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{1}} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right) & \lesssim C_{1}^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{1}} \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right) \\
& \leq C_{1}^{-1} C_{1} \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(R)=\widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(R)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have also used property $\mathbf{P}_{3}$ in Theorem 4.1. So the only case left to study is when 2) and $\mathbf{B}$ ) happen simultaneously.

In this case we apply again, for each $i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}$, the splitting given by Theorem 4.1 to all the parallelepipeds $R_{i_{1}}$. This way, we obtain a second family $\left\{\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} 1}, \ldots, \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} N_{i_{1}}}\right\}$ associated to each $R_{i_{1}}$, satisfying properties $\mathbf{P}_{1}$ to $\mathbf{P}_{5}$. Let us fix $i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}$ and observe that:

- Regarding property $\mathbf{P}_{4}$, now we have for each $i_{2}=1, \ldots, N_{i_{1}}$,

$$
\operatorname{diam}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right) \leq \frac{1}{10} \operatorname{diam}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right) \leq \frac{\sqrt{n+1}}{10} \cdot 2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right) \quad \text { and then } \quad \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right) \leq \frac{1}{5} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)
$$

This implies, in particular,

$$
2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right) \leq \frac{2}{5} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)<\frac{11}{16} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right)
$$

- Property $\mathbf{P}_{1}$ now reads $\frac{5}{8} \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \cap R_{i_{1}} \neq \varnothing$. Therefore, $2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \cap R_{i_{1}}$ are now parallelepipeds such that their maximal side length is between $\frac{11}{16} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)$ and $2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)$ (where we have applied (6.3)). For their side with minimal length, we distinguish:
A) If it happens

$$
\ell_{\min } \geq \frac{11}{16} \max _{i_{2}=1, \ldots, N_{i_{1}}} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)
$$

then the parallelepipeds $2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \cap R_{i_{1}}$ have minimal side length between $\frac{11}{16} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)$ and $2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)$.
B) If on the other hand

$$
\ell_{\min }<\frac{11}{16} \max _{i_{2}=1, \ldots, N_{i_{1}}} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)
$$

now the parallelepipeds $2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \cap R_{i_{1}}$ have minimal side length bigger or equal than $\min \left\{\ell_{\min }, \frac{11}{16} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)\right\}$ and smaller or equal than $\min \left\{\ell_{\min }, 2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)\right\}$.
For each $i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}$ and $i_{2}=1, \ldots, N_{i_{1}}$ we call $R_{i_{1} i_{2}}:=2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \cap R_{i_{1}}$. Two cases may occur for each $i_{1}$ :

1) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is satisfied for $E:=R_{i_{1}}$, that is

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right) \geq C_{1}^{-1} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{N_{i_{1}}} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)
$$

2) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is not satisfied for $E:=R_{i_{1}}$, that is

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right)<C_{1}^{-1} \sum_{i_{2}=1}^{N_{i_{1}}} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)
$$

We are interested in proving $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right)$ for every $i_{1}$, since if this is the case, arguing as in (6.2) we are done. The only indices $i_{1}$ where we would not be able to deduce $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right)$ are, again, those for which 2 ) and $\left.\mathbf{B}\right)$ occur simultaneously. For such indices $i_{1}$ we would again apply the splitting provided by Theorem 4.1 to every $R_{i_{1} 1}, \ldots, R_{i_{1} N_{i_{1}}}$ and construct for each $R_{i_{1} i_{2}}$ a third family of cubes $\left\{\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} 1}, \ldots, \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} N_{i_{1} i_{2}}}\right\}$. Now, for each $i_{2}=1, \ldots N_{i_{1}}$ one similarly obtains

$$
\ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} i_{3}}\right) \leq \frac{1}{5} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right), \quad \forall i_{3}=1, \ldots, N_{i_{1} i_{2}}
$$

and that $2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} i_{3}} \cap R_{i_{1} i_{2}}$ are now parallelepipeds such that their maximal side length is between $\frac{11}{16} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} i_{3}}\right)$ and $2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} i_{3}}\right)$ for each $i_{3}=1, \ldots, N_{i_{1} i_{2}}$. Regarding their minimal side lengths we again distinguish cases $\mathbf{A}$ ) and $\mathbf{B}$ ) in the current setting. Finally, for each $i_{2}$ one calls $R_{i_{1} i_{2} i_{3}}:=2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} i_{3}} \cap R_{i_{1} i_{2}}$ and studies two cases:

1) If assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is satisfied for $E:=R_{i_{1} i_{2}}$,
2) or if assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is not satisfied for $E:=R_{i_{1} i_{2}}$.

Combinations 1) $\mathbf{A}), \mathbf{1}) \mathbf{B})$ and 2) $\mathbf{A}$ ) lead to the estimate $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right)$. If one obtained such result for every $i_{2}$, proceeding as in (6.2) it would yield $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(R_{i_{1}}\right)$, and we would be done. However, 2) and $\mathbf{B}$ ) may occur simultaneously for some indices $i_{2}$. In this setting, we would repeat the above splitting argument for the families $R_{i_{1} i_{2} 1}, \ldots, R_{i_{1} i_{2} N_{i_{1} i_{2}}}$ associated to those $R_{i_{1} i_{2}}$ where 2 ) and $\left.\mathbf{B}\right)$ occur.

We repeat this processes iteratively and we notice that after a number of steps large enough, say $S \geq 1$ steps, $\mathbf{B}$ ) will no longer be satisfied. This is due to the fact that relation (6.1) ensures $\ell_{\min } \geq \kappa>0$, for some positive constant $\kappa$ depending only on $R$; and also because the size of the cubes at each step strictly decreases. Indeed, at step $S$ of the iteration, property 4 in Theorem 4.1 and the fact that $R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}$ has maximal side length bounded by $2 \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right)$ imply

$$
\ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \leq \frac{1}{5} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right) \leq \cdots \leq \frac{1}{5^{S-1}} \frac{1}{10} \ell_{\max }, \quad \forall i_{S}=1, \ldots, N_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}
$$

So choosing $S$ large enough, depending on $\kappa$, it is clear that $\mathbf{A}$ ) will be satisfied instead of B). Therefore, whether if 1) occurs, or if 2 ) and $\mathbf{A}$ ) occur, one equally deduces (arguing as in (6.1) in the latter setting),

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right)
$$

So tracing back all the steps of the iteration one gets, in general, $\widetilde{\gamma}(R) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(R)$.
Corollary 6.5. Let $E:=R_{1} \cup R_{2} \cup \cdots \cup R_{N}$ be a finite union of disjoint closed parallelepipeds with sides parallel to the coordinate axes. Then,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E)
$$

Proof. The iterative scheme of the proof we have given for Lemma 6.4 can be also applied in this case, but now taking into account the parameter

$$
\delta:=\min _{i \neq j}\left\{\operatorname{dist}\left(R_{i}, R_{j}\right)\right\}>0
$$

More precisely, for example, at the first step of the iteration it may happen:
A) $E_{i_{1}}:=2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}} \cap E$ has one connected component (and thus it is a parallelepiped) for every $i_{1}=1, \ldots, N_{1}$.
B) Or there exists an index $i_{1}$ such that $E_{i_{1}}$ presents more than one connected component.

We would also distinguish whether if:

1) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is satisfied for $E$.
2) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is not satisfied for $E$.

If 1) happens, we are done. If 2) happens, observe that if in turn A) occurred for every $i_{1}$, applying Lemma 6.4 and the same estimates of (6.2) we would also be done. So we are left to study the case where 2) occurs and there exist indices $i_{1}$ so that $E_{i_{1}}$ presents more than one connected component. In this setting, we would repeat the above argument for the every compact set $E_{1}, \ldots, E_{N_{1}}$, based on the splitting given by Theorem 4.1. We repeat this process iteratively, that is: at step $S \geq 1$ of the iteration we would obtain (for a set of the form $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}$ (where we convey $\left.E_{i_{0}}:=E\right)$, with multiple connected components consisting of parallelepipeds) a family of cubes $\left\{\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1} 1}, \ldots, \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1} N_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right\}$ with diameters comparable to $5^{-S} \operatorname{diam}(E)$. Now we would distinguish the cases
A) If $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}:=2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}} \cap E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}$ has one connected component for every $i_{S}$.
B) Or if there exists an index $i_{S}$ so that $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$ presents more than one connected component.

As well as

1) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is satisfied for $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}$.
2) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is not satisfied for $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}$.

The possibilities 1) $\mathbf{A}), \mathbf{1}) \mathbf{B})$ and $\mathbf{2}) \mathbf{A})$ are good in the sense that lead to the estimate $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right) \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right)$. If on the other hand $\mathbf{2}$ ) and $\mathbf{B}$ ) occur simultaneously, we would move on to the next step of the iteration, by applying again Theorem 4.1 to each $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1} 1}, \ldots, E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1} N_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}}$. The key point, however, is that for a finite number of steps $S$ large enough (depending on $\delta$ ) we would have $5^{-S} \operatorname{diam}(E) \ll \delta$, so that B) can no longer happen, and thus we obtain the desired estimate tracing back all the steps of the iteration as in Lemma 6.4.

Remark 6.2. Observe that in the proofs of Lemma 6.4 and Corollary 6.5 the constants appearing in $\widetilde{\gamma}(R) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(R)$ and $\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E)$ do not depend on the minimal side length $\ell_{\min }$ of the parallelepiped $R$ in the first case, nor on $\delta>0$ in the second; both being strictly positive parameters. Such quantities, however, do determine the number of steps needed to carry out the iterative argument of the proofs. But this is not an issue, since the constant appearing in assumption $\mathbf{A}_{3}$ is precisely taken to be $C_{1}$, the same constant

of property $\mathbf{P}_{3}$ in Theorem 4.1. This enables to carry out the estimates of (6.2) and avoid any possible dependence on $\ell_{\min }$ or $\delta$ when tracing back each step of the iteration, since $C_{1}$ cancels itself out with its own inverse. Again, let us remark that this type of argument has been inspired by that of [Vo, §6].

Let us apply Corollary 6.5 to the usual family of corner-like Cantor sets of $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$. Let $\lambda=\left(\lambda_{j}\right)_{j}$ be a sequence of real numbers satisfying $0<\lambda_{j}<1 / 2$. Define its associated Cantor set $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ by the following algorithm. Set $Q^{0}:=[0,1]^{n+1}$ the unit cube of $\mathbb{R}^{n+1}$ and consider $2^{n+1}$ disjoint cubes inside $Q^{0}$ of side length $\ell_{1}:=\lambda_{1}$, with sides parallel to the coordinate axes and such that each cube contains a vertex of $Q^{0}$. Continue this same process now for each of the $2^{n+1}$ cubes from the previous step, but now using a contraction factor $\lambda_{2}$. That is, we end up with $2^{2(n+1)}$ cubes with side length $\ell_{2}:=\lambda_{1} \lambda_{2}$. Proceeding inductively we have that at the $k$-th step of the iteration we encounter $2^{k(n+1)}$ cubes, that we denote $Q_{j}^{k}$ for $1 \leq j \leq 2^{k(n+1)}$, with side length $\ell_{k}:=\prod_{j=1}^{k} \lambda_{j}$. We will refer to them as cubes of the $k$-th generation. We define

$$
E_{k}=E\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{k}\right):=\bigcup_{j=1}^{2^{k(n+1)}} Q_{j}^{k}
$$

and from the latter we obtain the Cantor set associated with $\lambda$,

$$
E=E(\lambda):=\bigcap_{k=1}^{\infty} E_{k}
$$

If we chose $\lambda_{j}=2^{-(n+1) / n}$ for every $j$ we would recover the particular Cantor set presented in $[\mathrm{MPr}, \S 5]$. Let us introduce the following density for each $k \geq 1$,

$$
\theta_{k}:=\frac{2^{-k(n+1)}}{\ell_{k}^{n}}
$$

where $Q^{k}$ is any cube of the $k$-th generation. We also set $\theta_{0}:=1$. Combining Theorem 3.5, the results of $[\mathrm{He}, \S 4]$ and Corollary 6.5 we deduce:

Corollary 6.6. Let $\left(\lambda_{j}\right)_{j}$ be a sequence of real numbers satisfying $0<\lambda_{j} \leq \tau_{0}<1 / 2$, for every $j$. Then,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{k}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(E_{k}\right) \approx\left(\sum_{j=0}^{k} \theta_{j}\right)^{-1}
$$

where the implicit constants only depend on $n$ and $\tau_{0}$. Moreover,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E) \approx\left(\sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \theta_{j}\right)^{-1}
$$

Proof. The result for $E_{k}$ is a direct application of [He, Theorems 4.1 \& 4.2], Theorem 3.5 and Corollary 6.5. To obtain the result for $E$ notice that for each generation $k$ we have,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \leq \widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{k}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(E_{k}\right) \leq \gamma_{+}\left(E_{k}\right) \approx\left(\sum_{j=0}^{k} \theta_{j}\right)^{-1}
$$

Therefore, using the outer regularity of $\gamma_{+}[\mathrm{He}$, Proposition 3.1] we get

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \lesssim \gamma_{+}(E) \approx\left(\sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \theta_{j}\right)^{-1}
$$

and by Theorem 3.5 we are done.
6.3. General comparability for compact sets in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. This subsection deals with the proof of the following result:

Theorem 6.7. Let $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{2}$ be a compact set. Then,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(E) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}(E)
$$

Proof. Let $E \subset \mathbb{R}^{2}$ be a compact set, that we assume without loss of generality that satisfies assumptions $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{1}}$ and $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{2}}$. So in particular $E$ is contained in the unit ball and consists of a finite union of dyadic cubes belonging to a dyadic grid in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$ (with sides parallel to the coordinate axes), all of the same size and with disjoint interiors. We denote by

$$
\delta:=\text { diameter of the cubes of the dyadic grid. }
$$

Again, we repeat the iterative scheme of Lemma 6.4: in general, at step $S \geq 1$ of the iteration we would obtain for a set of the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}=E, & \text { if } S=1 \\
E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}=2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}} \cap E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-2}}, & \text { if } S>1
\end{aligned}
$$

a family of cubes $\left\{\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1} 1}, \ldots, \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1} N_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}}\right\}$ with diameters comparable to $5^{-S} \operatorname{diam}(E)$. Now we would distinguish the cases
A) If $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}:=2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}} \cap E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}$ has diameter smaller than $\delta / 4$ for every $i_{S}=$ $1, \ldots, N_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}$
B) Or if there exists an index $i_{S}$ so that $\operatorname{diam}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \geq \delta / 4$.

As well as

1) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{3}}$ is satisfied for $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}$.
2) Assumption $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{3}}$ is not satisfied for $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}$.

If 1) occurs we are done, in the sense that we can deduce the estimate

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right) \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right)
$$

If 2) occurs, we move on to the next step of the iteration up to the point where $S$ is large enough (depending on $\delta$ ) so that option $\mathbf{B}$ ) is no longer possible. That is, the iteration stops once the only two possible scenarios are: 1) or 2) $\mathbf{A}$ ). In this setting, we are left to study the case where 2) and $\mathbf{A}$ ) occur simultaneously. To deal with this case, we write the precise definition of $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$, which is

$$
E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}:=\left(2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}} \cap 2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}} \cap \cdots \cap 2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \cap 2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right) \cap E=: 2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}} \cap E
$$

where $R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$ is a rectangle with diameter comparable to $5^{-S} \operatorname{diam}(E) \ll \delta$. In fact, applying properties $\mathbf{P}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{P}_{4}$ in Theorem 4.1 at each step, one easily deduces the inclusions

$$
\frac{11}{16} \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}} \subset 2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}} \subset 2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}
$$

The latter is trivial for $S=1$. If $S>1$, the argument is similar to one that is presented in the proof of Lemma 6.4. For example, if $S=2, \mathbf{P}_{1}$ yields, for each $i_{2}=1, \ldots, N_{i_{1}}$,

$$
\frac{5}{8} \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \cap\left(2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}} \cap E\right) \neq \varnothing, \quad \text { so in particular } \quad \frac{5}{8} \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \cap 2 Q_{i_{1}} \neq \varnothing
$$

On the other hand, $\mathbf{P}_{4}$ yields $\operatorname{diam}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{2} i_{2}}\right) \leq \frac{1}{10} \operatorname{diam}\left(2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}} \cap E\right)$, which implies

$$
\ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}}\right) \leq \frac{1}{5} \ell\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}\right), \quad \text { for each } \quad i_{2}=1, \ldots, N_{i_{1}}
$$

All in all, one easily gets $\frac{11}{16} \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \subset 2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2}} \cap 2 \mathcal{Q}_{i_{1}}=: R_{i_{1} i_{2}}$, which are the desired inclusions. Such scheme can be repeated at each step to obtain, in general, relation (6.4). The latter inclusions imply that the rectangle $R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$ behaves as a square, in the sense that its side lengths are comparable and thus, by the second statement in Corollary 6.3,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \leq 2 \gamma\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \approx \gamma_{+}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \leq \frac{16}{11} \gamma_{+}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right)
$$

That is, $\widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right)$. In addition, since $\mathbf{A}$ ) occurs, by the definition of $\delta$ we get that $2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$ can only intersect one connected component of $E$. Moreover, if $2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$ intersects one of the dyadic squares that conform $E$, it can only intersect, in addition, those squares which are adjacent to it (a maximum of four). Therefore, there is only a finite number of possible compact sets that $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}:=2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}} \cap E$ can be. We represent them in Figure 1. There, $2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$ is assumed, without loss of generality by (6.4), to be a (red) square; and some of the dyadic squares conforming $E$ are depicted in gray.
It is clear that in cases $a$ ), $b$ ), $c$ ) and $d$ ), a direct application of Lemma 6.4 yields

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right)
$$

Regarding $f), g$ ) and $h$ ), we write $2 \ell_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}^{H}$ the horizontal side length of $2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$, and $I_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}^{H}$ the horizontal side of $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$ with such length. Then,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \leq \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(I_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}^{H}\right) \leq \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right)
$$

where for the second inequality we have used the second statement in Corollary 6.3 and relation (6.4), and the third follows simply by the monotonicity of the capacity. Hence we also obtain the desired estimate. Finally, case $e$ ) can be dealt with in a similar way, just noticing that at least one of the diagonally opposed rectangles $R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}^{\uparrow}$ and $R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}^{\uparrow}$, obtained in $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$, presents horizontal side length half of $2 \ell_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}^{H}$. Assume it is $R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}^{\uparrow}$. Then,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \leq \widetilde{\gamma}\left(2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \approx \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(I_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}^{H}\right) \leq 2 \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}^{\uparrow}\right) \leq 2 \widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right)
$$

Therefore, in all possible scenarios we get

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right) \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}\right)
$$

so applying the same type of estimates of (6.2) (since we are assuming that $\mathbf{A}_{\mathbf{3}}$ is not satisfied) we deduce

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right) \lesssim \widetilde{\gamma}_{+}\left(E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S-1}}\right)
$$

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1. In black, the eight possible intersections that can be obtained from $E_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}:=2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}} \cap E$, for $S$ large enough so that $5^{-S} \operatorname{diam}(E) \ll \delta$. In red the rectangle $2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$ (assumed to be a square by relation (6.4)), and in gray some of the dyadic squares conforming $E$. Let us remark that in $d$ ) we also contemplate the case where $2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}} \cap E=2 R_{i_{1} i_{2} \cdots i_{S}}$.
the necessary estimate to trace back the iterations and obtain the desired result.
The previous result combined with the fourth statement in [He, Proposition 3.1] yields:
Theorem 6.8. The capacity $\widetilde{\gamma}$ is semi-additive in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. That is, there is an absolute constant $C>0$ so that for any $E_{1}, E_{2}, \ldots$ disjoint compact sets of $\mathbb{R}^{2}$,

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}\left(\bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty} E_{j}\right) \leq C \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(E_{j}\right)
$$

# 7. FURTHER RESULTS IN $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. THE $\widetilde{\gamma}$ CAPACITY OF RECTANGLES 

In this section we compute the $\widetilde{\gamma}$ capacity of a closed rectangle $R \subset \mathbb{R}^{2}$ with sides parallel to the coordinate axes and respective side lengths $\ell_{x}>0, \ell_{t}>0$. More precisely, we obtain the following result:

## Theorem 7.1.

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(R) \approx \ell_{t}\left[\frac{1}{2} \ln \left(1+\frac{\ell_{t}^{2}}{\ell_{x}^{2}}\right)+\frac{\ell_{t}}{\ell_{x}} \arctan \left(\frac{\ell_{x}}{\ell_{t}}\right)\right]^{-1}
$$

Proof. Let $R \subset \mathbb{R}^{2}$ be such a rectangle and assume, without loss of generality, that its lower left corner coincides with the origin. To simplify the computations, we also normalize its temporal side length $\ell_{t}$ to be 1 by dilating $R$ by the factor $\lambda:=\ell_{t}^{-1}$. We name the resulting rectangle $R_{0}$, that is such that

$$
\widetilde{\gamma}(R)=\lambda^{-1} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{0}\right)=\ell_{t} \widetilde{\gamma}\left(R_{0}\right)
$$

We introduce the parameter

$$
r:=\frac{\ell_{x}}{\ell_{t}}
$$

that is nothing but the spatial side length of $R_{0}$, as well as the measure

$$
\mu:=\left.\mathcal{L}^{2}\right|_{R_{0}}
$$

By a direct computation, one obtains that the potential $P * \mu$ at a point $\bar{x}=(x, t)$ is given by the following explicit expression:

$$
